Great place to build a career
A very enjoyable and professional place to work.  Management provided excellent environment.  Varied clients and job duties made for interesting work.

Always busy, everyday a bit different, can get stressful, but what job isn't. I learned a lot about myself and how to better manage myself and my time. Most people are great to work with and will be happy to help you out. The hardest part of the job for me was trying to make everyone happy at one time. For me the happiest part of the job was knowing I did my best and 9 times out of ten I was successful at what I did.
Management and co-workers are supportive, and willing to help new comers. A working culture of diligent and detail-oriented. Great IT supporting team.
An amazing fast phased environment to work. This is a nice place to work with great experience

I enjoyed working with my team. We worked long hours but always got the job done. The hardest part was the long hours. The most enjoyable part, was that my team was fun to be around. I also learned so much about the hedge fund industry in financial services.
I have afunny work atmospher even we woreked very hard .
Good hours but not a lot of work on a consulting job. Sit around for hours at a time.
KPMG has alot of "stay"  power as many of my colleagues that started with them years ago are still there with them.   They are a great employer, keep in touch with their alumni and foster community.

The firm is a nice place to work with a lot of friendly people; however there are times when I struggle with work/life balance and that is the hardest part about working here.  Additionally, the pay is ok, but not great.

Manage logistics all day.  All of my co-workers are nice and friendly, but I am looking more for a career that will allow you use my current work experience to make an impact in other areas of business.  I am more interested in business strategy and my current role doesn't offer that.  I highly encourage anyone that likes to project management to work in my function.

KPMG was a good experience for me but I was over qualified for the position and moved on to a more challenging position. A typical day would consist of requests from various departments to fix locks on cabinet doors, replace light bulbs or get details for internal staff moves. What I learned was that although KPMG was that we had over lapping department that were capable of performing multiple tasks but weren't and we were a lot of man hours because. My co-workers were legacy employees who felt as if they were with the company long enough to be considered managers and would make it difficult to get requests fulfilled because they didn't want to take direction from new managers, but overall they new their job responsibilities but just lacked the education to move on the next level.

My experience in transaction services has been great.  Partners within my particular group genuinely care about their employees and are easy to communicate with about your career and goals.  The work is intense and time sensitive, but if you are in transaction services then that is what you are looking for.  Generally everyone in our group is highly motivated, intelligent, and skilled in financial in analysis.  It is pleasing to be around co-workers that all pull their weight and where everyone wants to learn.  You are also at the front echelon of mergers and acquisitions which is exciting.

KPMG does a wonderful job trying to create a comfortable, inclusive, working atmosphere. They hire some amazing people and almost everyone I have worked with has been great. You are pushed into very unique situations from day one and you are forced to grow quickly.
Busy work life but exposure to various engagements and learn a lot.

Great company, good benefits, work life balance is encouraged, diversity networks are an added benefit. Jumpstart on Fridays in the summer months are a great way to start the weekend, departing at 3pm, companywide. Jeans Fridays.
Very busy but well balanced.  Homey environemnt.  Supervisor was great.  Was able to advance.  Staff was very well balanced.  Great location.
Opens many doors. Great exposure to accounting in different industries.

I loved every aspect of my internship at KPMG. From the first day onwards, I was learning new skills and being provided with opportunities to hone in on old ones. My coworkers were all very fun and supportive of me, each other, and the firm as a whole.
I've learned to work under stressful environment. It was a very productive place.
This place is a hiring mill.  People come and go very quickly.  Staff are used to the max.
Great coworkers and excellent benefits. Exposure to various clients and working in different warehouse and manufacturing environments.

KPMG LLP, the U.S. audit, tax and advisory services firm, operates from 87 offices with more than 23,000 employees and partners throughout the U.S. Our purpose is to turn knowledge into value for the benefit of our clients, our people, and the capital markets.
KPMG Business Schoold offers options for one to learn other areas in the training industry.
I enjoyed my time working there. Everyone was really nice and a  hard worker.

Het leukste van deze baan is de verscheidenheid van klanten. Je kwam telkens in een ander bedrijf binnen, waar telkens een andere manier van werken werd gehanteerd. Het nadeel van mijn werk was de weinig toegevoegde waarde, het doel van onze werk was om de fouten in de boekhouding te vinden. De significante fouten vonden we meestal enkel terug met behulp van de eigenaars van onze klant. Bij elke klant werkte je samen met andere collega's, hierdoor kon je telkens bij leren van andere collega's.
Great place to start, a bad place to remain! Every group is different. If you end up in a good group you are lucky, if not, too bad -- go look for another job.
The most enjoyable part of the position was learning from very intellegent people, namely those to whom I reported to: PMO, Director of IT and Infrastructure, and the Director of QA.
I was there for just a short time but liked the people in my department.
Productive and fun place to work. Great team and work environment.
Everyone I've worked for or worked with at KPMG have always been professional, kind, friendly, and always there to lend some assistance.
Challenging, but resulted in a greater understanding of business efforts for an undergraduate student.
Work is fun steady and it's a great teamwork environment. Management is wonderful. The job is not hard, but very busy. I really enjoy working with my coworkers
Very busy and long hours. Overall great benefits. Not much room for advancement in my position.

Current job satisfying but because KPMG is a rather large company, it can be a challenge to connect with professionals outside of immediate team. Opportunities for support (non-client facing) professionals are limited.
Could not have enjoyed my time there any better. They treat you like a person.
skip this work place;
Managing Large Complex engagement

KPMG provides a great foundation for learning and career advancement.  There are endless resources and opportunities at anyone's hands.  However, the work-life balence is pretty bad, and only gets worse as you move up the corporate ladder.

I loved every aspect of my internship at KPMG. From the first day onwards, I was learning new skills and being provided with opportunities to hone in on old ones. My coworkers were all very fun and supportive of me, each other, and the firm as a whole.
This job had no work-life balance at all. I initially joined the company hoping for great work experience and the opportunity to travel. All I have to say is BE CAREFUL WHAT YOU WISH FOR!
work with your team, client and another third parties to accomplish the plannified work for the day, week, month. Besides the normal job the are administratives activities that need to be complete.
Unless you enjoy workplace intimidation, excessive hours, very little training with little appreciation, and being micromanaged.
The benefits and pay are great, but you sacrifice work life balance.
KPMG is an excellent company, lots of smart people.  The Marketing group is a challenge to work in given that KPMG is a Partnership.

Great emphasis on learning and developing through experience. Learned a great deal about liquidation and other advisory services. Developed a strong and professional attitude for client communication.
Great place to work

Arrived at the audit client site, planned daily work with the audit senior, requested support from client staff, prepared work papers, reported to audit manager on audit findings and work progression.
I was a part of the Support Services team in 2005 and felt like a vital part of the business. The employees were helpful and nice also.
High performance culture.  Everyone is geared to get the job done.
great management
KPMG is a good place to work at. People working at KPMG are very smart and also very dedicated to their work.
I mainly work 9 hours per day.  We work in teams and share the responsibilities providing financial improvement and audit readiness.
A good learning environment with nice people. Learned the ins and outs of KYC and AML due diligence in relation to BSA regulations. Investigated well over 600 cases.
An entry level position that is all. Door to door that is all that is needed to know about this place.

Big 4 CPA (CPA obtained in Mexico) professional with extensive international experience. Strong experiences auditing financial statements in accordance with IFRS, USA GAAP and MEX GAAP. Excels at reviewing accounting processes and internal controls to identify potential process improvements; including focusing on IT Systems. Self-starter who can work independently and has the motivation required to handle and meet deadlines on multiple projects simultaneously.
Pros:

	KPMG international is a Swiss cooperative that serves as coordinating entities (Hazem Hassan) for a network of independent terms operating under the KPMG name which consider from the largest providers of financial services all over the world.

It's a lot of work, but you learn a lot. The hours are what cause most people to leave since as you work your way up more and more is required of you and there is never enough time in a 40 hour workweek to take care of everything you need to.

Excellent hands on training, amazing training program providing opportunity to travel and stay in the best hotel!  Fun and outstanding team members and clients to work with and learn from, flexible working arrangement and well structured management. The most enjoyable part of the job is to see the final product of our engagement and see our client to publish their annual 10-K report to the SEC!

Good place for a first job, not the best for a second career.  Very competitive internally with strict hours and required extended periods, even when work is not available.  Had to maintain a positive work-life balance.

KPMG is such a large company that it is hard to generalize it, but I went in there as a consultant from my industry and I was in for a rude awakening.  They preach all sort of things like "Charge the hours  that you work" etc but then you will always be indirectly told to eat hours.  In my department, finding work that was a good learning experience and not mind numbing was hard to come by. good company but not good work life balance. It is a good place to start with. You learn and practice accounting and auditing standards everyday.

Bait and switch on the job expectation - hired in to work for great executive, got switched to executive that no one wants to work for and burns thru assistants at least twice a year.
Good place to work. Good environment . Good Management. Good worklife balance. Flexible.

I just wanted to express my appreciation for all the work that Paul Rzyski does on a daily basis. Every day I see evidence of his presence from the cube farm, break room and even in the Quite room. I love that he stocks the supplies and I have never had to hunt down cups and eating utensils in our area. I am especially grateful the refrigerator by the Coke machine is always clean. He is a diligent worker.
The overall culture of KPMG is a great culture. A typical day is about 10-12 hours depending on the account.

At least in the Montvale office, where we are all considered backoffice slugs, the atmosphere is unbelievably negative. You are constantly treated as if you are a horrible disappointment and unworthy of your position - and this applies to everyone below the director  level.  Altho most of us are at least as well educated as the consultants and accountants - and offer far more educationally qualified - we have no clear career path, no support and face a general attitude of disdain and dismissal. It really is horrendous - and I would strongly advice anyone to find any other position before taking one here. Sadly, the faltering economy has left many of us stranded here. It's akin to a hostage crisis - but without the Stockholm syndrome

During the busy season a typical day at work would star at 9:00am. You get to the client, you are presented with the cash, PP&E, Revenue, Expenses audit program from prior year (PY) and then you star working on the completion of the work papers (WP) assigned to you. At lunch you usually go out with the members of the team. The day usually ends at 11:00pm and you'll probably work on the weekends as well. The hardest part of the job are the hours and the pros are all the knowledge you get. You are exposed to many areas and therefore you see a little bit of everything and learn a lot.

In my 9 years with KPMG, I have gained valuable experience working in three different positions, have dealt with people of different backgrounds and been involved in different work functions (advisory, training, and local support). On the day of orientation, along with about 50 others, when it was my turn to introduce myself, I was very proud and excited to be becoming a permanent full-time employee after being a temp-to-perm employee transitioning from an employment agency. However, I was immediately "knocked down a peg" by one of the people doing the orientation. I explained that I "went permanent" on X date, and she immediately responded that "nobody is ever permanent" "we just let you use this job". I thought that to be a very rude and counterproductive attitude. However, once I began work, I enjoyed working in an upscale environment. I was issued a laptop as though it were no more than a clipboard. The down side of that was that I had to carry it home daily and be responsible for it. The worst part of the job was that I was supposed to be in training, yet the girl assigned to my training wasn't training me. I had no idea what was expected of me. When I would ask questions of our supervisor, I would only get vague answers that never helped. The trainer was eventually fired, and still, no one properly trained me, and later on, I myself was let go without warning or explanation.

In new employee orientation (along with about 50 other people), I was excited about being employed with such a prestigious company. I was immediately knocked down by a person performing the orientation when I said "I went permanent on X date", she replied "nobody's permanent, we're just letting you "use" this job". I thought that to be a very rude and counterproductive attitude. However, beyond that, I thought the perks of working in an upscale office were good. At the time, laptops were assigned as though they were clipboards. The down side of that was that you had to carry it home daily and be responsible for it. Our department moved from the prestigious Peachtree St. office to a regular office off of West Paces Ferry shortly after I began. The strange part was, I was NEVER officially trained in the job I was hired for, and had no idea what was expected of me. Then the girl who was supposed to be training me was fired, and shortly thereafter, so was I. I was never given a reason.
KPMG is a great place to build your career. I have enjoyed my experience here.
Typical workday is hectic due to billable hours. Stressful environment and coworkers are pressured. Hard for career advancement. Management only care about themselves. Work life balance is poor.

I have been working for KPMG about 3 years and have watch my life outside of work disappear. I no longer have time for the things in life that I love; going to the gym, my dog, my husband and family. If you want to work 70 hours plus a week and watch the rest of your life and hobbies disappear, this is the job for you.
Really enjoyed working in this environment with CPA's MBA's and J.D.'s. The Partners, Management, Staff and Administrators where top notch people.

A typical day of work for the first 6 months entailed going to all the team members to beg for work because they were all too busy to let the new guy help.
Good experience with numerous different industries and service offerings
KPMG LLP, Advisory Services, New York, NY (Feb 10 – Dec 11)

A typical day at KPMG was planning an audit. This means checking emails, preparing the current and permanent files for the next audit. working on three to four different audits, meeting with the clients, preparing a clients deliverable list for the clients. Conducting entrance and exist meetings with the clients, filedwork at the clients's business, preparing Management Letter points, audited draft financial statements, training on auditing procedures, analyzing and reviewing the financial statements to ensure accuracy and no errors. Research foreign currency rates for investment securities the Bloomberg System. Review clients' corporate documents at Legal Firms. The majority of the audits required team work unless it was a small audit where one individual did the audit. I worked with a diverse group of people from different cultures around the owrld and I enjoyed working with the team, I developed friendship with most of them and we remained in contact with each other to this day. The hardest part of the job was seeing persons with so much knowledge and skills leave the Company to pursue other careers. Management at KPMG had an opened door policy and was very respecful to all of its employees.
The experience at KPMG is very challenging. The hours were very long but along the way I met a lot of interesting and like-minded people and was able to walk away with many life-long friends.
I LEARNED ALOT ABOUT FINANCIAL REPORTING AND HOW TO TEST CONTROLS.
Reporting directly to Managers/Directors/Partners and working with major national and international clients.
Managermet Care for employees.
Excellent place to build your career

I had a great career at KPMG (Tax) and I left there after 19 years. The firm gave me so many challenging opportunites such as working in federal tax, state tax, professional practice, overseas position, etc. In addition to that, I worked with so many smart people who helped me along the way which gave me a great skill set.
Terrible place to work. No work/life balance. Lots of politics in management, boring, depressing work environment.
I learned a lot I never knew there was some much going on in the record department and I would love it,

I spent most of my first year auditing a mortgage company and a real estate investment company. My second year I spent most of my time auditing a major credit card company. I spent a lot of time during my second year ensuring Sarbanes-Oxley compliance. My managers taught me a lot during my time there and I was able to work with some hard-working and intelligent co-workers. I most enjoyed getting to see many different businesses and how they worked.

Provided a robust supporting role on numerous operational risk management engagements for major corporate clients, gaining familiarity with all levels of client organizations, and completing numerous complex tasks, including:
A professional work environment. Management is concerned about their employees. I enjoyed the organization and problem-solving of my daily duties.
Great benefits and top pay. Management is top notch. Work with top folks in their field. High performance culture. Fair work life balance
A typical day was providing administrative duties for my Vice President and staff.

A typical day at work was always fast paced. Constantly working with project teams to help create budget files, forecasting project economics and coordinating invoicing processes. Meetings were held frequently during the week with Partners, Senior Managers and Managers. My coworkers were very supportive yet very demanding. This was my first job in a huge company, therefore I learned so much relating to time management, relationship building, and working with a dynamic group of people. The most enjoyable part of my job was the traveling advantages. I attended training classes in other cities as well as having quarterly meetings in Seattle and Los Angeles. The hardest part of the job was learning how to prioritize since the work load was fairly heavy; it constituted a lot of overtime.

I loved every aspect of my internship at KPMG. From the first day onwards, I was learning new skills and being provided with opportunities to hone in on old ones. My coworkers were all very fun and supportive of me, each other, and the firm as a whole.
In charge of the southwest US for commercial property tax appeals. Handled shopping centers, office buildings and warehouse property types.
Work 8:00 am to 5:00pm

The position provided room for growth. I assisted with software and hardware on laptops and desktops, I also wrote a 99 page User Guide on Windows 95 with KPMG software. Other duties included assisting with server backups, performing troubleshooting on equipment in Annapolis City buildings and training users if needed on any software or hardware issues. It was a great place to work.

The work itself is almost always dry so your enjoyment of the job really depend on the people you are working with. The problem is, teams change very often, and about half the time, there will be someone on your team that will just ruin your day. I mean it may just be my specific experience but I think because of the nature of the job and the emphasis on selling work to advance to manager the most ambitious, people tend to make manager and tend to be very aggressive and not very nice. I'm sure this is true for all Big 4s though so no big deal.
This firm is a model of efficiency, performance, quality, a job well done in a timely manner, and satisfaction beyond expectation.
No two days are exactly the same, which I like. There is no work life balance.
Opportunity to travel and meet different types of people from different places.
Great company to work for - highly intelligent professionals, great benefits and investment in employees.
Prepared tax returns. I learned how to use Turbo Tax on the job. My manager was a very nice lady, and she was extremely mannerable. My co-workers were really nice and very warm.
Good place to work if you want to learn. People are quite friendly.
KPMG provides a good place to work with extremely complex workstreams that provide great opportuinities to develop out-of-the box solutions.
Great place to learn and apply skills learned in school and become a working professional.
I worked on the following different clients:

In my current role I am a member of the program management team in the KPMG Business School - Audit. A typical day for me consists of creating project management documents and leading weekly status update calls. I work with strategic partners to ensure the successful delivery of training for the audit professionals within the firm. I have experience in working with various levels at the firm. The programs that I have managed range from campus new hires all the way up to partner.
Incredible experience where I learned a lot of human resources. Very nice people too.
There are partners and then there are the rest. Manager work crazy hours trying to make partner.
Friendly organizational culture, challenging work. Excellent office campus, good facilities.
KPMG is a great employer where I gained alot of knowledge and experience
Friendly people on the client side. Good interaction with employees there.
Senior strategy and change practitioner focused primarily on transformation programmes to support an ambitious growth agenda

I loved every aspect of my internship at KPMG. From the first day onwards, I was learning new skills and being provided with opportunities to hone in on old ones. My coworkers were all very fun and supportive of me, each other, and the firm as a whole.
If you enjoy being an office drone, working in a cubicle, hardly ever seeing the light of day this job is for you.
Excellent experience gained in top 5 US/International Banks; 100% travel.

Run like a feudal system--partners vie with each other for power and control and every employee needs a partner prince to protect them and their job. recent changes in the past few years have seen a dramatic rise in outsourcing to India with the result that many loyal employees were let go despite their credentials. There are many wonderful folks here but alas many key players just do not care about anything other than their own advancement.
Great place to work with great people. There is always room for growth and learning.

Even with set duties, each day was guaranteed to bring new challenges and a way to enhance or learn new things. The environment was that of a small company with corporate benefits. Over the years, co-workers become friends which made going to work a pleasure.
For the most part a nice to group of people to work with. Every day was different. Having to do the multiple time and expenses - was a challenge at times.
What can you say, Big 8, great experience, I was young and worked allot.
KPMG is average with respect to most but does provide a very realistic work/life balance.

A typical day at work includes project coordination, calendar management, meeting planning, travel planning, office space coordination, conference room scheduling, call screening, email follow up, document printing, scanning, copying and filing, letter and bill processing and mail sorting and distribution.
Pros: decent pay, interesting opportunities, company is implementing a number of initiatives to improve knowledge, tools and competitiveness
If you like consulting, this is a good fit. Most consulting firms are the same thing with different clients.

Assisted in audit services to several clients of different industry nature including financial services, manufacturing, automotive, real estate, software design and governmental. Conducted year ended and cycle inventory counts for several clients of different industry nature including governmental. Obtained training and CPE credits (139 hrs.) in several topics (accounting, auditing, business development, ethics, and computer science).
Team-oriented environment. They provide excellent benefits.
Solid management team in trust tax group, but concerned about long-term. Lost biggest client and cut from 95 staff down to 30 in 2008.
KPMG is a great firm to work for. They tend to hire the "best of the best" and retain those people by giving people challenging, technical and creative projects to perform....from day one.

My coworkers and partners are extremely knowledgeable -- very creative and fast-paced individuals that are always willing to help. The environment has been beneficial to develop a professional skill set. A typical day includes a variety of account management, reporting, event planning, internal and external networking, as well as proposal and collateral creation.
KPMG is a great place to start a career. They provide you with multiple opportunities for skill building and networking that prove valuable throughout the lifetime of your career!

Process new hoteling space for employees from other locations. How to read diagnoses. Management was pleasant. Cowokers was very nice. Hardest part was trying to read the doctors hand writing and the most enjoyable part of the job was gifts and getting off early

A typical day at work was normally at the client's work site. We performed audit procedures to give an opinion on the accuracy and reliability of the financial statements. I learned how to test internal controls as well as substantive testing. To be able to test accounts on the balance sheet and income statement it was necessary to have an understanding of the company's operations. During my time at KPMG I learned a vast knowledge of how companies operate and the accounting that went along with it. The people who work at KPMG are extremely intelligent and hard working. I have great respect for all of my co-workers. The hardest part of this job was during "busy season" where long hours were expected. The most enjoyable part of my job was the people who I worked with and the opportunity to be exposed to new challenging work.
Conducive growth environment for new and seasoned professionals.

I loved every aspect of my internship at KPMG. From the first day onwards, I was learning new skills and being provided with opportunities to hone in on old ones. My coworkers were all very fun and supportive of me, each other, and the firm as a whole.
learned technical skills and knowledge of generally accepted accounting principals
Good place to start your career, but you should expect long hours and low salary.
The nature of tax work is very backward look and did not fit well with my forward thinking outlook.
They were dedicated and it was a great place to work - with great work/life balance options that I will miss.

KPMG is a global leader in audit services and naturally enforces a high performance culture within the firm. The firm has great job growth potential and the fast paced learning environment really enoucrages entry level associates to pick up on responsibility and learn audit and project management skills early on. The young atmosphere also inhibits a great learning environment that makes it enjoyable. However the job is very demanding and despite the firm's efforts to maintain work/life balance it becomes very difficult to do so with multiple busy season and traveling.

KPMG is a great work place in which one can learn and grow quickly. On any given day, an audit associate's workload can include performing testwork over various audit areas, such as revenue, meeting with clients for follow-ups, preparing memos and excel tables for testworks, etc. The most difficult aspect of this job is balancing multiple projects or assignments and meeting deadlines. Specifically, the amount of work increases significantly during busy season and the difficult part is managing various projects simultaneously. The enjoyable part of the job is the flexibility to work in many different teams and meet and interact with numerous clients.

As has been typical of Big Four public accounting firms, the hours were many more than I had been told they would be - 60 hours a week. Shortly after joining the firm, I was asked to begin helping the Kansas City and Omaha. I was asked to begin flying to Kansas City bi-monthly and it ws likely thst I would be asked to relocate.

Overall this is a good place to work. The hours can be long but that is expected in public accounting. I love being able to work with people my age and on teams. The amount of driving you may end up doing is outrageous.
Such a beautiful environment to work & highly recommended. Would always love to get a job at a company like KPMG
Long hours, low pay. Get in, get your experience, and get out to make some money.

The working environment provides for numerous opportunities to gain exposure to upper level management as well as key accounting principles. Work days range from 8 hours during summer months to greater than 12 hours during the busy season (January through March). Each engagement is unique and provides a different working environment in relation to the size of teams and the frequency of manager presence. Associates are typically responsible for more routine accounting areas such cash, prepaids, accounts payable, fixed assets and investments. Testwork includes tests of operating effectiveness over the control environment as well as substantively testing year-end balances through trend analysis and/or selections of individual transactions. Challenges include completing all audit testwork within a short-period of time while staying in the parameters of the established budget. However, the job allows associates to communicate with staff accountants, controllers, and at times, CFO’s which quickly builds on networking and communication skills.
KPMG provides a work environment where you are challenged on a daily basis and are given opportunities to grow professionally.
Employees are overworked in an effort to keep costs low. Efficient work is discouraged by the large emphasis placed on billable hours. Unhealthy workplace with unrealistic expectations.

KPMG is a great place to build a career in professional services. In my almost five years with the firm I have been continually challenged with interesting work and tight deadlines. The skills you learn from working in this business environment are invaluable.

KPMG is always on the cutting edge providing continous learning which has kept me current with emerging issues in industry. I have learned great people management skills working there. My co-workers are great at providing internal support on technical topics and always lending a hand during busy times. One of the things most enjoyed about my role as senior manager is being provided with the freedom to manage my own schedule while meeting clients timelines with quality service.

KPMG is a great company to work for. For anyone wishing to excel in the accounting field, starting off in a public accounting firm is the way to go, simply because of the wide breadth of experience you will attain by working with them. I was definitely pushed to work harder while with the firm and you learned to manage my time and work a lot more closely with a big team of individuals. The work environment is nice - it's always easy to reach out to any of your superiors and be treated as a person. The hardest part of the job is being able to construct a solid work/life balance, as you will find yourself working around the clock practically all of the time.
My life was living out of a suitcase here. It was a great experience but I traveled alot to Europe to US. I was hardly ever in boston.
Good place to gain work experience. Company is strong only in financial auditing.
Managed internal application project development.

1) Company has been more focused on growth therefore has led to a lot of pressure on the management group. Within the Advisory practice as a Manager or Sr Manager you are required to sale and also run projects. Can become overwhelming at times.

I loved every aspect of my internship at KPMG. From the first day onwards, I was learning new skills and being provided with opportunities to hone in on old ones. My coworkers were all very fun and supportive of me, each other, and the firm as a whole.
Co-workers on my team were wonderful to work with to resolve process problems or client questions.
Great resume builder, not a place where any sane human being would want to spend their career.

Working in KPMG help me to develop time management skills, interpersonal skill and how to effectively work in team. The challenge of the job was working on more than one project or with more than one client at a time but i effectually developed the skill to do that.
Large international accounting firm is a great place to work! Very interested in continuing education of employees; great benefits; job securitty; personal and professional growth potential.

My experience thus far has been average - 2.5 stars would better represent my rating. Unlike other places I have worked, I don't sense the level of cohesion within the Milwaukee tax group that I have previously experienced in public accounting and that I believe to be essential for maximum efficiency and productivity. The group seems disjointed and I believe the "we" and "team" mentality is absent. Furthermore, the Milwaukee tax group lacks the partner level of leadership that I very much need (and have previously had) at the level I am at in my career. As far as the audit and advisory partners/leaders in Milwaukee, I have had positive experiences similar to the very positive feeling from my exposure to tax partners and leaders in Chicago.
For tax you will prepare various tax returns and tax provisions.
This was the company that became BearingPoint. Same big 5 Consulting model.
A wonderful opportunity, but the cost for promotion is 80-100 hours per week.
It is a great place to be. You learn a lot, great exposure to external and internal clients
Enjoyed my time there but left because of he work/life balance issue.
Poor pay and manager is a dead wall. Makes everything frustrating because people lie to you to your face and do nothing when expressing concerns.

The money is good, but the Cypress office does not know how to conduct themselves in a professional manner. Cypress, KPMG is still making up the development rules as they go along. This job needs around 3-4 people to test the product properly. You will be bullied and blamed for not being able to do the job of four people, while this job lasts. The people in this particular office are holdovers from Arthur Anderson's failed firm. This office is full of office politics. If you have experience with hand to hand combat you might survive.
I am very proud to had worked in KPMG now Bearing Point. Courses every time, excellent managers, well organised.
If you want to join a company with a strong sense of team and commitment to excellence, where quality matters. This is the firm for you.

The consulting services group is a dynamic, well trained group. Clients are among the who's who of world business. The consultants are among the best in the world. The range of assignments is widely varied and very challenging.
excellent training availability and really seemed interested in molding associates to be the best

I can't really tell wich part of my job was the most enjoyable; all my job was because i liked what i was doing, the people with who i was working the whole environement made me really enjoy it and it was mutuel every body was enjoying working with me because of my personnality i'm a listening personn i love to learn and i guess the best way to learn is to listen to people who has more experience and even the one who has less that i do,i believe in that each day a human being spent on the earth he learn a new thing and this will be the case until the last day of his life

This company had the usual perks of a cpa firm, but without any of the appreciation or joy that comes with. Everything was done better, smarter, faster at Andersen. Gave the impression they were slumming by coming to any other cpa firm (kpmg in this instance) and showed no loyalty or respect to anyone who wasn't from Andersen. Very uncomfortable.
Good if you are looking for job security.

It is a very professional company. The people who are working here has very outstanding working ethic. The manager in KPMG treat us not only professionally but also nice and sweet. No pressure but full of energy to start a week day every single morning.
A lot of organizational and managerial changes but overall, New Relic is a wonderful company that treats employers well. A good place to start a long and fulfilling career.

NR was Wily 2.0.  Founder had previous experience in this space so it was great to work for someone who already had a vision on how to build an enterprise company from the ground up again.  This was key within divisions in engineering, marketing, support and sales.

It was a great place to be an intern. I learned a lot about the different facets of marketing within the technology industry and how to leverage the strengths the company to appeal to new potential customers.
New Relic is people focused and strives for innovation, learning and career growth.

New Relic is a place for the brave and disciplined. I learned that individuals that lack self-discipline are quickly identified, those that meet the rigorous yet rewarding daily life as a Relic can achieve professional cloud 9.
Great Product & good place to work with. Good place to learn & great leadership team.

I think the company is doing great things and they have one of the top products on the market. They have all the free snacks, barista,  occasional lunches and other perks you could ask for out of a San Francisco office. From my perspective if you got a good manager and territory you were set and if not then you drew the short end of the stick and would struggle. Expect all the growing pains of a start up.

If your successful here its because they give you the leads to make the $$.  Management thinks they have talent but they're just in a good situation and they'll never leave because they know they dont have any talent.  Not fair at all.  Work somewhere else, this "bro culture" isn't for women or normal SF citizens.  Very very FAKE
Managers put their egos before customers.  Anyone that spoke up had seriously consequences.  There was a severe female to female bullying problem that leadership was aware of and did nothing.
I loved working here and am still friends with plenty of my ex co-workers. The CEO pushes for work/life balance and that sentiment carries forth through the rest of the organization.

Management doesn't interact with others. Only care about being profitable and raising the stock price. Managers provide no career plan for advancement and don't give opportunities for growth. First time managers get barely any training and don't really know what they're doing.
It was great, but has been steadily changing and many of the smart, talented people that attracted me to this company have left. The culture has changed dramatically in the past year.

New Relic is a viable business with aspirations to be the "next Salesforce" in the Application Performance Management space.  The CEO is a passionate leader who delegates managing the business to his team.
Not much to say, this is a great company.  The product is world-class.  The people are great and fun to work with.  The espresso bar is a major perk.  Location can't get much better
New Relic is a startup darling that went public.  Lots of focus on the individual and great team culture early on.  Post IPO, it became political and great people were either let go, or moved on.
I don't wish to write a review at this time.  It was a good company that was going through some restructuring.  I recommend you do your own research if you are interested.
While there are a few talented individuals at New Relic, they are stifled from doing their best work by some truly terrible managers, directors, and VPs. Cronyism is rife.
All around good company to work for.  Had management issues when I was working there, but has changed significantly since my departure.
Great products and wonderful innovation.
Title says it all -- heavy turnover in last 12 months and mgmt is okay with folks leaving.

Worked there a little over a year - it's a roller coaster ride but a great place to work. Surrounded by smart people that are passionate about the software that want to be there. The culture is all about being authentic and challenged.
A lot of organizational and managerial changes but overall, New Relic is a wonderful company that treats employers well. A good place to start a long and fulfilling career.

Typical day I would just sit at the front desk waiting for people to come in. I didn't really have the opportunity to learn much. My manager only wanted to take responsibility away from me. I like most of my co workers, but not everyone was approachable.
- Great work life balance for IPO ready company

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.
Fun workplace with passionate co-workers. If you love pets and helping pet owners, this is the place for you. However, you must have passion for it because the pay is not there.
Work hard paid not so hard. Not easy to advance and if you do you are over worked. Trading commission is okay but only if you can sell tons. A lot income store doesn't do that
My time here was super slow paced and everyone just seemed like they just wanted to go home, which is valid. Employees were occasionally nice but overall it was depressing.
The Culture Petsmart has created is great. I felt welcomed and had an overall good time in the DC. Pay is good, they were very flexible with me going to school. I had no real complaints.

The coworkers and managers will talk behind your back. Tips are okay, most of the coworkers would belittle you or make you feel incompetent. They would schedule you without telling you and get mad you didn't show up. Its okay but be prepared to do more work and yelled at for not being "fast enough"  don't be ontime but 5 minutes early

Overworked and underpaid sums it up. I enjoy working with the dogs. I just started out about a month ago as a bather and will be attending the grooming academy, hopefully. I wasn't aware that I would have to give up every weekend to work and plus closing at all times.
This was a nice start to my career working with animals. The basic training provided for animal care was sufficient and helped guide me to more focused animal welfare efforts.
I did not like working there because of the way they treated the small animals. Staff was cool. But the birds and fish were not treated the best. It was om for a starting job

The job itself isn't too bad, but the only thing leadership cares about is making money and keeping customers. Not all managers care about their associates and the ones that do are few and far between. No matter what a customer does, if they complain to the manager or corporate they get what they want

I feel that corporate doesn't understand the needs of the store with the hours given to us. we usually close the store with 3 people and this is ok sometimes. However over the past year it has not. During the evening shifts we often on busy days only have 3 people on in the store with one cashier, one leader and one pet care associate. I order to provide the best customer service the leader is forced to chose whether to become back up cashier, help customers or help in pet care when they are backed up. Our customers reflect their experience with this in customer surveys.

PetSmart wants to pay you the minimum and then give you every task known to man. Someone called out? Too bad. Figure it out without them. Didn’t get everything completed due to lack of staff? Too bad, here’s your write up. Need to call out because your legitimately sick? Get over it and get to work. You tested positive for covid? Well why’d you come to work sick? Because you made me!! I seriously cannot stress to you enough... there are not enough words in the English dictionary for me to explain to you and caution you on how awful company is and how it drains you of every spark of energy that you think you have! And then they wanna play the whole “make associates feel like they belong” .. “we care about you and your health” .... Total front. Not to mention the lack of support. You’ve got one person over here with their head so far up the SL’s cheeks that you’re unsure of which one is actually the SL. Another one over here busting it, while that person over their is getting all the credit. Just don’t. Don’t apply. I’m gonna stop now. But I could go on for days.
It's fun to play with dogs at PetsHotel but unfortunately Petsmart is very bureaucratic with too many policies that get in the way of common sense, leading to high turnover.

When I began at Petsmart 10 years ago, it was a great place to work. But this gradually changed to what it is now: a place where the store and services employees are treated like chattel, while upper management at the home office in Arizona issue decrees from on high that aren't in line with in reality. Store and services workers are expected to perform an ever increasing amount of work with less -- less pay, less labor hours allocated, and less support.

The supervisors and team leads are clicky and don't let anyone they don't like succeed. They change their opinion about agents within a day and will randomly pick people to abuse their power. You might be sitting with a team of 18 people and then the next day 9. Quality Assurance and other parts are bogus for the most part and can't actually help the agents grow. They let people work from home in waves when the pandemic first hit because they didn't fund enough equipment in preparation. and they made some of us stay for like 3 months into it all, also the people chosen to work from home were not picked based on performance or tenor, but rather favouritism (THE WORST PART) and barely any compliance with social distancing. I had other people around me who literally just got done traveling across state within 14 days and I got covid from them. When I told them about my concerns they brushed it off every time with a "yeah... unfortunately that's just how it is [*Smiley Face* :)  if it was an IM just to be even more petty.] And also because its like company protocol to have no expression of worry and a "CAN DO" attitude the whole time even when just casually speaking to peers on break. Not really a ton of room to move up and if you mess up once on like your first day, you have to wait like 6 months to have that problem removed from your account.
The store is great my dogs loves to go there and the people are nice and you guys have lots of food brands and toys that I love and they love to I like cats to and …

I worked here in college and it was okay. My manager was okay but the pay was minimal and my raise was 25 cents...which is ridiculous. Customers were nice. There didnt seem to be much culture at my store.
I absolutely love working here. I worked at another big retail store before transferring to the life of pets and I cannot express enough how much happier I am now!

the job is relatively easy; being a cashier, stocking shelves, and a heavy focus on customer service. customer service/getting sales is their biggest priority. don’t get sick and call out, or they’ll get upset.

I worked in the PetsHotel area of PetSmart and I can say it was quite fun. You get to work with dogs and sometimes cats but it kind of sucks cause you have to clean all the gross stuff but after awhile you get used to it. The managers made sure you had your break and there is room to grow! I was almost promoted (at the time I only worked for a few months) but then covid came so that blew right out the window. One big con is that the managers and team leaders had no back bone. If there was a serious issue with an employee they would barely do anything. Or if someone wasn’t doing their job right, they would say something one time but that was it and then get mad when the employee would do it again but still they wouldn’t do anything about it. But other than that still a decent job.

At first working here was ok, however I quickly learned that every one else was making more than I was and getting a raise is close to impossible. Made me bitter about going the extra mile and not getting any recognition for it. I was a petcare specialist, however they often would put me to work on the register which no one wanted to do. Also management would often make “jokes” or degrade petcare staff making it seem like their job was easier than it was. The only good thing about this job that I can think of it was that it was easy to call out of/get days off or people to cover for you.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

Being told from day one about going to grooming school is the only thing that has kept me going, the pay is absolutely absurd barely covers my phone bill & food, i do like getting paid weekly but that is probably the only plus side to this job. Expected to not only do about 4-6 dogs in 5 hours but also expected to answer every phone call (managers only care about the customers) & help the groomers with whatever they need done because THEYRE running behind. I feel that I am treated like i’m a peasant lol. On top of all of that we are extremely limited on hours as bathers which barely gets me $200 a week talk about SAD. I do not recommend this job if youre starting out because you WILL be promised so much more than you will be given. Do not expect a lot out of this job as the company only cares about making their money & not helping their employees or making the daily workplace any easier.

Mostly my shift started at 4am to work the truck, but sometimes I would work the register. It’s an okay job but it comes with big box store issues, like chronically being short handed. It’s like they hired and kept employees who didn’t care about their jobs.

Great job to work as a part time college student. Managers in north 10th put customers first and bend over backwards to answer any questions. Pay is great hours are very flexible and managment is near perfect.
Management is awesome
I love working petcare. Everyone is friendly and the manager is flexible with my schedule. Animals are number one priority with each employee! Definitely recommend

The management is helpful and understanding. The culture within my store is very accommodating and friendly. People accept you for who you are and love to point out the good things you do. There are opportunities to move up, especially if you're willing to relocate.

Too many dogs, not enough associates to care for them. Pay was abysmal for all that we had to put up with. I got plenty of hours because of the high turn over, but I was always stressed with all the dogs I had to care for myself since we were pretty understaffed. Also management was cutting corners in terms of "walking" the dogs.

This is by far my favorite job so far! The managers are awesome and everyone I worked with was so nice. Being around animals every day was such an amazing experience and always brightened my day up. I formed an attachment to all my regulars at doggie day care.

Usual understaffed even pre-covid creates a fairly stressful environment. Even when staffed the company does little to create an inclusive environment. Employees often create a hostile workplace for each other and solutions are not team building. They do not practice any kind of team building so it's to be expected that information between employees isn't fluid. Communications are often minimal which can be confusing. Animal care knowledge is minimal as well and it's often beneficial for employees to spend personal time educating themselves. This can often lead to frustrations as the focus is in sales of products. However, scheduling tends to be on-demand as low staffing creates openings for either extra hours or specific hours. Pay isn't competitive and level caps without a ladder system for advancement means raises are low.

Definitely a company that sees you as disposable. Managers and corporate make it very clear that they do not care about you unless you’re boosting their numbers. Worked at more than one location and always saw managers that were under qualified for their jobs or just overwhelmed by the workload. Salon teams are usually constantly overwhelmed, expected to each groom up to 6 dogs a shift while also being expected to answer the phone that rings off the hook all day. You start out as a bather and then end up going to academy to be a groomer (if your manager even wants you to). Pay for the bather position is trash and 100% not worth the manual labor that you do. I lost 30lbs as a bather and wasn’t out of shape to begin with. Policy says you’re not supposed to lift over a certain weight but the groomers never have time to help you lift dogs so you’re on your own.

Management sucks and tends to pick favorites,very repetitive, pay isn't worth what they put you through, expect you to do everyone else's job including theirs without giving extra pay. But working with the animals is alot of fun..

The Petsmart I have worked at is very small but has some of the nicest customers that come in. Often people ask questions for petcare and how to properly setup animal husbandry. Of course there is always a odd person here and there who are a bit spiteful. But overall great place to work.
Great to work with animals and be able to talk to others about animals, but pay is limited and the only advancement requires early morning stocking shifts.
Hard place to work when you have children.  My pay was not great for the amount of work required.  It is taxing to deal with angry customers so much.  I enjoy working with animals
You get to do a ton of stuff when you work at petsmart and it is especially fun for animal lovers, But just like any retail job it has its cons, which if you're used to it won't be a bother.
The pay is too low compared to the work put in. Some days I’d have to clock out for my lunch and immediately go back to work just so I can finish the dogs on my schedule.

I've had a couple good store managers here but for the most part management is a joke. I worked in grooming. Their training is ridiculously bad (I was trained elsewhere). They say they want quality over quantity but that's a lie. All corporate looks at are numbers and couldn't care less about you as a person. Grooming management is either power tripping or looking to move on or both. If you know what your doing you can make more money being a groomer. They write their policy and procedures for inexperience and stupidity.
Been with them for three years always willing to teach and promote from within.  Most stores setup very similar so easy to move within the system for promotions.

Coworkers are generally good, I enjoyed them quite a bit but the management is always on your back and ready to reprimand you for your work no matter the situation without opportunity to explain yourself.

Pet Smart can and has been in the past, a great place to work. They pay me well. The down side is advancement. I am teaching my boss his job and he just can't catch on after 9 months. He makes the big money while I am hourly.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.
This was the best job I've ever had. I worked in the PetsHotel and PetSmart takes care of their employees. We got free speakers to use in the DayKamp center and it was great! Highly Recommend.
The best part of this job is seeing the animals. The hours are long and repetitive. Working the trucks can get repetitive, especially if it's the same stuff over and over.
fun place to work with room for growth, management helps you when they can. have responsibilities to care for the animals, which is a good thing. Nice customers too
Corporate is always looking at the numbers and micro manages. Focus on your negatives more than your positives. Yet to hear them compliment me or a coworker.

Felt under appreciated as an employee! At the end of the day it was only about the numbers! They often punish employees who have appointments or go home sick by cutting their hours down. When you put in your notice they list you as no rehire!

My team is by far the best part of my job. I’ve worked at PetSmart for 3 almost 4 years. I worked my way up a regular associate to management.  At first it was great but with covid hours were cut regardless of how busy all the stores have been with “quarantine pets.”Corporate keeps taking away required tasks or telling us to do them less often to justify the lack of hours but doing things like animal counts less often make numbers much less accurate and it takes me more to to do them once a month than it did once a week. We still have the same amount of tasks to complete and not enough hours. It has made the job very stressful and I feel as though there is never enough time in the day.

I love my coworkers and working with animals. However, PetSmart is very much a large corporation that values quantity over quality in almost all areas. Compensation definitely needs to be higher, especially for those working directly with animals. Again, I love working with animals, but I come home sore and covered in bruises and scratches every single day. I feel as though they should be paying us more for the physical labor and risk of injury.

Work sometimes gets busy during weekend afternoons. Management seems to care for employees, and form connections. Employees seem to trust one another and gets along well. Petcare associates know their stuff and try to give customers good advice, but oftentimes customers ignore us. You will sometimes deal with angry customers but management will always intervene to help you out. Overall a good place of belonging. Most workers are in college though.

Working in the salon is fun and the dogs make it almost worth it. However it is an underpaid position for the amount of work and customer service aspect. Work-life balance is abysmal. They’ll say they evenly try to schedule weekends and holidays, but you will be there for weekends and holiday. Once heard a manager discouraging employees to grow their families.

The best part of working for Petsmart is getting to see all the regular customers and their pets as long as they are responsible pet parents.. Besides for that....petsmart used to be a pretty good company.  Of course like all big companies they are always trying to be more profitable so they keep cutting labor. They've cut so many hours, positions in the store that it's impossible to get your work done.  I've worked with an amazing team that stuck with it all through covid but it's finally becoming too much.  We're starting to lose some amazing staff members because their done with corporate piling on more and more, all the while paying low wages and pretending they care.  No. Petsmart does not care about any of their associates or they would give back some hours so our petcare team isn't overworked. Cashiers are always stressed out because now it's only 1 vs having overlapping coverage. They are tired of being the only cashier and hearing customers complain constantly because merchandise isn't on the shelves.... that's because we get very few hours for stocking, long lines....because there's only 1 cashier.

They give very little training and then if you make an error they rate you up immediately. They also will cut your hours in half without telling you till you see it and they do not accommodate for appointments

PetSmart was a great company to work for when I started 15 years ago. Over the years the company cut hours until the stores were constantly understaffed. It became less important to offer excellent customer service than to save as much money as possible on overhead and as a result you can expect to make less money for more work and deal with more justifiably irrate customers who will cause you more stress than you need. I stuck with it as long as I did because I was and still am passionate about teaching people about their pets, but now that I have the opportunity, I prefer to either find an organization that takes pride in the actual work of dog training, or starting one of my own.

While the job has a lot of upside, the downside certainly outweighs it. Regardless of your position there is much to be done and no time to do it. Management is poor as far as communication and although they preach we work as a team, everybody is only does tasks that benefit themselves. Most everybody is quick to point fingers when something is done wrong or a mistake has been made, and just as quick to take praise for the good that has been done. To anyone seeking employment at petsmart, be prepared to lose your soul.
The job isn’t too bad. The dogs were the best part of the job. It was nice once you got a good clientele in place. Being trapped in that glass room was sometimes annoying.

I was hired in 2015, right after they were bought by their current owners but before the current p&p was established, so I have an unfortunately unique view of seeing the decline of the company. I really, really loved my job from 2015-2017, and then due to frequent manager changes and policy changes, it became a much more stressful and hostile work environment. It was more difficult to get animals to the vet, care commitments were changed for the worse, etc.

Fast paced at times but over all pretty relaxed. The petcare position was fun, and all of my co workers were easy to get a long with. This position is for people who are truly passionate about working with animals and puts a lot of care into taking care of them. Cashier position also isn’t too bad, rarely were there rude customers.

I love the job itself even though it can be stressful in the petcare department. But the managers make it unbearable sometimes. Never agreeing on what they want so they are constantly telling you different things and chewing you out for it. Plus the hours are horrible.
I liked working for petsmart because you can always advance. Biggest downfall is its a corporation. Im just personally not a corporation type of person
It was good for a college job, but the customers tear you down. You're told you can deny sales but then your DM tells you you're not allowed, as it will lead to bad customer reviews.

I worked for petsmart as a Groomer for 10 years. The turn over is so high. Groomers are pushed to groom more and more to make the store more money all the while they are expected to still answer phones, book appointments, check in clients, and spend at least 10 minutes with each for check in and check out. People who have never groomed sit around and come up with ideas of how to make a salon better but have no idea what they are talking about.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.
Hard physical work, but can pay off if you're a groomer. Bathers get paid hourly while groomers start at 40% and after completing academy go to 50%
Overall, It serves a purpose, you get paid weekly. Schedule comes out 2 weeks in advance so you can plan a life outside of work. I like being able to move around and try new departments.

Not bad but not great either. Worked directly with dogs so I didn't have to deal with customers which is a plus for me. Worst part is when no one wants to dump the waste buckets the shift before leaving with a mess

Never enough staff to give good customer service yet we were told it was up to us to make sure every customer was taken care of. Poor management. Company constantly told grooming salon workers that safety came first but did not provide them with the tools and staffing needed to always put safety first. Always feeling pressure from company to up-sell and groom more dogs than possible.
Good. Liked the people. Different for each person and store. get to see animals and meet a lot of nice people. i had a lot of fun working and 10/10!!!
The things that stand out to me working here are the passion from the other employees about the animals they care for and send out to good homes. I've learned a lot from them in my short time here.

They are money driven don’t have a care about the animals health or the groomers if a groomer doesn’t feel comfortable they push the groomer anyways or force the pet onto someone else. Short breaks if you got them the people there are very rude and not team players managers only care about how much money you could make they have favorites. They work the ones who will work to death to the point they hate their jobs and the ones that call out constantly or show up late all the time are fine never get in trouble.
This was a good place to work, however I was not given the position I applied for. I got hired for pet care, but instead of working for pet care I only worked the register.

These things really depend on the region and individual stores. That being said, pay is seldom adequate and not evenly distributed. If you accept a lower wage thinking it will go up, it may take years. People with no experience will make more money just starting out, but employees that have been there over 5 years will have only received a yearly 10 cent raise if their performance was ranked well. Job can be enjoyable if you need something temporary or have other income to rely on. You can learn a lot about differerent animal and fish species if you take the time to read on your own time.

Great job!! usually on weekdays in the morning there would be nothing much to due, but you still got paid hourly so you could see yourself sitting around for about 1-2 hours doing nothing (this depends on which store you're applying for), aside from the occasional walk-in. They sometimes hold special adoption days, where you can meet with future customers and dogs. the job usually includes making appointments, cleaning (sweeping, cleaning the bathing area, etc...), grooming and bathing the pets that come in, and answering customer questions, which they go over in their training period (which you get paid for). You get paid a decent amount of money and you also get tips. Overall great place to work at!!

Getting to see happy and loving animals everyday is a huge plus, but it’s a retail job very focused on sales. Typically its very easy to request time off and see family, but being a part time associate does not yield any benefits outside of a paycheck. While the staff I work with are awesome, the grind of a corporate job focused on sales and reviews will weigh you down and all you can do is try and provide the best information/advice for a pet parent, but more often than not, they will not take your advice and either return an animal they did not research and blame you or the animal suffers. It is a very hard cycle to be part of as an animal lover. You will learn all sorts of tips and tricks here for taking care of animals though, even from my role as cashier! Be prepared to only receive a lunch during an 8 hour shift though, it is near impossible to receive a break. There is rarely enough help either.
It sucks. Pay Is awful, pet parents are entitled and management sucks extremely. I don’t recommend working here unless you want to have the life sucked out of you.
Worked there for a little bit as a pet care associate, management was great. Fun if you like animals, if you don't, why are you applying, part time pay not the best, but alright
pretty good job i had good co workers i never thought the benefits would be this great free lunches YUM i eat on the job and i use the bathroom to vape

I worked there for about two years and I ended up getting trained in all areas except for training, management, and a groomer but I was a dog Bather trying to become a groomer. I was told by one of the lower managers that if I got trained in most of the jobs at the store I would be able to become full-time. Which I manage to learn almost all of the positions But unfortunately they worked me almost full-time hours for a couple weeks and then I would get one really low week so that way they could keep me  as part time. And when I became a dog bather trying to become a full-time groomer they kept pulling me out of my training to help them back out on the floor. Then when it came time for grooming Academy I ended up not having enough training hours to become a groomer and there wasn’t going to be another one For seven more months. I was a very dedicated and hard-working employee but that did not matter they did not want me to be full-time because then they would have to give me benefits

The store management overall are great but Corporate does not listen to their employees. I was not happy about how Corporate treated their cashiers. They forget we can make or beak a store. Cashiering is so key to the store. I will say my store leader was fair and wonderful to work for
I enjoyed working here because I love animals but if you get bad management it will make the time here miserable.

It's PetSmart. The one I worked at didn't care about their employees, the managers would constantly make fun of other managers, employees and customers when no one else was around. They maybe flexible with your schedule but they'll complain about it. And one of the managers over the early morning stocking would call you at 8 pm that night to make you come in at 1 or 2 in the morning when your scheduled to come in at 4 or 5 without warning.
Since it is cooperate your constantly waiting on a higher up and it feels like your not important or ‘annoying’ your mangers. But overall it’s a good support system in the store I worked at.
The staff got along really well. Training was good. The business was very organized and professional. I enjoyed working there. Unfortunately I had to leave because of unexpected health issues.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.
The job was okay. We were always short staffed and many people would quit. Some of the managers showed favoritism and other would work harder than others.
Very good place to work. Good management. Great customer service. Fun environment.  Flexible work schedule.  Overall a great place to work especially if you love animals
If you work here use it to you’re advantage management is hit and miss; be there for the education not the job or the money. Be ready to get out when your contract is up.

The job is very fast paced and there’s a lot that needs to be done during your shift. If you’re fully staffed it’s a pretty smooth process but if you’re ever short staffed it really makes the day difficult to get through. Working with the dogs is rewarding and overall the job is cool but just be prepared for unexpected stress.

Worked there a long time and enjoyed it when we were a smaller company. As we grew the family feeling went away. Managers get moved around a lot so you never settle in with one group of people before they move out and new people move in.

The pethotel was gross, staff and management were extremely lazy and judgemental. There was no outside area for the dogs to go to the bathroom they just potty in their rooms or in the playroom. The playroom only got cleaned twice a day and the rooms rarely got scrubbed. Nasty.

At a store level, it is an interesting and fun place to work. Home office decisions are confusing and sometimes unwarranted, sometimes even detrimental to the success of the store. Even though they offer advancement opportunities and training, seems as if though in order to move up, it'd be better if you were an outside higher. Clear evidence of advancement, but after a decade or more of being within a store.

This job is not worth the money spare yourself. PetSmart policies try to protect their animals legally, but their emphasis is on blind sales. Most of the employees have no idea about care for animals or the products they need to sell with animals. Most employees did not care about the animals at all let alone have any knowledge about them to help a customer. Daily I would have to step in and explain to a customer how to care for their pet and what their pet needed because there was only a handful of people in the store that knew anything about the pet. Breaks are short. Store was not cleaned properly. Terrible management, no teamwork or communication.
You'll often times find yourself doing work that you didn't sign up for unbeknownst to you. The managers are pretty lazy and will drain the life out of you if you let them.

There is some toxicity within the grooming salons based upon expectations and locations in the area. You are expected to make a large profit for the company, so cycling through dogs is more important than the finished product. Some management doesn't uphold the policies  as strictly while other management does. At the same time some are more lenient on schedules than others. It all depends on which location you work at, and what values you hold onto.
Not enough staff or time to get the job done. Irregular schedule and working with people who hated being there. Out of touch upper management who look down on employees.

Not supportive to you, deletes your online enrollments, they want you to be on register and you have no time to prepare for classes, do training paperwork and ylu have to share your space with the PetsHotel but receive but I was told they would sell boot camp classes for me, they have done none. Management sucks, and I recieve 20% commission when I do 100% of the work

I've never seen so many managers in and out in a company. My Store leader is very arrogant and likes to be intimidating. So many good employees and managers left because of his lack of leadership  skills.

I worked in the Petshotel "Mostly overnight shifts"  I've never had so much fun in a workplace. The dogs and cats were amazing and on the overnight shift you can work at your own pace, as long as everything is done by the am shift, everything is cool. You can play music and hang out with doggies all night...

Generally, PetSmart is a good place to work. I have found that the company sometimes works on too many priorities at the same time and is very slow to provide the resources in terms of headcount needed to get the job done. You have to know when to say "I can't get to this right now" PetSmart can be a great place to learn because you get involved in a lot of things. Can you get promoted here? Yes, but it can take longer than you anticipate. It is also according to how your department operates and some have their favorites, making it hard for many to get opportunities to advance. The company does a good job at recognizing employees through cash awards and a points catalog.
