I can deal with it, but it would be so much better without that weight over your head.

Profit comes first in every situation, it's all about the bottom dollar and looking good for investors (they want to take the focus off the fact that the company is tanking). Employees are expendable, loyalty and seniority mean nothing. Associates who have worked there 15 years are routinely pushed aside to make room for fresh faces. It's fun when you first start, but management must take advantage of employees and ring out every last drop of energy in order to meet goals set by corporate fops who don't understand the day-to-day struggles of working in the retail and service industry. Associates are written up for 1 minute of overtime, but are expected to do double the workload of what is humanly possible. Breaks are nonexistent. Employees regularly work through lunch and after hours but are not allowed overtime pay so usually clock out and go back to work.
It's a good place to work if you love and animals, and assisting people with their pets needs. If you're not a people person this isn't the job for you.

Petsmart is HORRIBLE they treat thier employees like garbage and will openly tell you your disposable. Store level management cant be amazing but above that are all terrible. This is the most soul crushing company ive ever worked for.

I myself love dogs and love to wake up for a job where I get to take care of pets. I worked in the PetSmart Grooming area. I was there for a very short time, but it was the best job I ever had. The team was wonderful to work with and be around in general.
I love petsmart they are a kind and loving place. The management is stellar and I wouldn’t take my pet anywhere but to them because they love and care for them like no one else.

There is very inconsistent oversight by upper management. Many protocols not strictly enforced so the employee experience is profoundly different location to location. Store leaders/district leaders make or break the experience. I've worked with some amazing people over the years that motivated me to be my best, and I've worked with some who made me want to stop trying.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

I love working with the animals and dealing with the customers. Unfortunately we got the manager that came over from Target.  It could be a better run organization if they really wanted honest feedback from the employees.

it was ok until corporate forced management turnover and then became one of the worst companies to work for. it seems to be true even to this day from what i hear from current employees even if it’s been years since i’ve worked there.
It’s a great job but it’s more than just petting dogs and some people don’t really seem to think about that before apply, it can be stressful but overall a good job

Worked here for 15 years.  Loved it up until I ended up having to work everyday including on my vacations.  Got to be overwhelming.  I miss the environment, co-workers, pet parents and the pets most of all.

Management is horrible . Also did way to much work for what you do hates it. You ask for help and you never get it . You get treated horribly . When people say I would love to work there I tell them run

I honestly loved the work I did with this company. I got to love on and take care of exotic pets daily. Dealing with customer questions and concerns was challenging and rewarding. My biggest issues came in the low wages. Some new hires were being paid more than me after having been with the company for almost 5 years. One year I only got an 8 cent raise...who does that? I was promised on more than one occasion that I would be trained as a lead for an open position at my site, then was overlooked for an outside hire or an internal promotion of a teenager.

I worked in grooming, management doesn't care about employees and training is poor. You work hard for little money. I had good co workers but the company overall lacked professionalism. They treat their groomers like children.

When I first started I was under the impression that the salon and everyone that worked in it made plenty of money but I quickly found out that that wasn’t true. Working as a Bather was exciting at first because working with dogs and puppies seems fun but then it’s not. As a bather (at my store) I was looked down upon. All the dirty work fell to me. I would close the entire salon by myself Almost everyday. I went from doing 5-6 dogs a day to 13+ without any warning. I felt overwhelmed and overworked all the time. The pay is absolute garbage. While every groomer brought home at least $800, some making up to $1400 a week. I barely made $300. The amount of work that I did and how hard I worked that was like being spit on it’s insulting how hard bathers work and how little we're paid. I found out that I was making petsmart $1000s a week (more than some groomers) while I was only being paid $200. The management basically told me to deal with it whenever I confronted them about my pay. I loved working with the dogs but I hated how I was being taken advantage of. I wouldn’t recommend this job to anyone because you are literally the salons slave. I hope it gets better but I doubt it will.

I worked at 3 different stores, and they varied based on management and coworkers. The first store was my first job and I always felt appreciated and got along with my coworkers for the most part. The job can be boring at times, especially if you are constantly stuck on the register. However, I was able to transfer stores with ease, and move up fairly quickly.

Poor management throughout my store, but I'm a petstist, make 50% commission and work very hard so I'm a happy camper financially. I've spoken with corporate and it seems to be a great company to work for but it isn't necessarily reflected in the actual stores.

It was a good job, great coworkers and a place to get to know shoppers in your community. You have regulars that you get to know and their pets who you bond with. Coworkers can become friends for life but despite everything it's still retail. High expectations, some rude customers, poor consistency with management, poor hours and little flexibility unless you've been around long enough to earn it.

It's a great temporary job for people with little to no experience, who love animals and enjoy getting to learn about them. You don't make a lot of money in the beginning and they expect you to do more than a normal office/9 to 5 kind of job. Expect to clean, learn to work the registers and assist customers with everyday questions. Most of the staff is friendly, so definitely ask them questions when you aren't sure about something.
Typical retail problems. Not enough hours for people to be where they need to be. Pay was decent for any leads but GM was always overworked. Company takes short cuts long term for store well being
This is most definitely a starter job that I would work at while young. Management was ok and coworkers were fun to work with. Overall nice people to work with

It was okay but it got my foot in the door to work with animals. Management did not care at all about the animals. The hamsters all had wet tail, birds were stressed, cats in adoption died... just horrible stuff.

My time here was awesome and I loved it! I loved working with the animals and my coworkers and management were wonderful. Everyone working here was really nice and really enjoyed their job. They put in 200% every shift. Unfortunately I needed full time hours and the pay was a little lower... had I been able to be employed full time I would have never left. It really was a great place to work.

In my experience working there, the job was very much enjoyable. The work was fairly easy, managers were always very helpful and had your back most if not all the time. Very laid back environment, hardly ever any stress except for inventory time of the year or the holidays, but that's anywhere. I only left because of a personal dispute, but had that never happened, I would've loved to have moved up in the company.

This job started out great but it turned out to be one of the worst places I ever worked. The people that worked there were incompetant and extremely lazy. Nobody cared about the dogs all they cared about was where their next dollar was coming from.... Went through 3 salon leaders in 3 years and not one of them actually liked dogs or even liked their jobs. Upper management did nothing about complaints. Anybody that actually loved their jobs were smart enough to leave there.

I was a bather in the grooming salon, and I really enjoyed it at first, but they promised to send me through their grooming academy program to become a stylist, but it was easier for them to keep me where I was at, so they ignored me and refused to promote me. A family member of mine was suffering from cancer, and my first time calling out of my shift for going to the hospital with him, the salon manager told me to call my ONE coworker who was also a bather to cover my appointments for the day. After that, I turned in my two week notice, but I should have just quit outright. They don't pay you enough for dealing with large, rowdy, and difficult dogs, and I frequently got back injuries from having to bend over all day long to bathe and groom dogs that had to be tethered to the floor, since they were too big to fit in the tubs. My one store was bad, maybe others were better, but that was my experience.
Bosses don't care about how you are treated. Just worry about getting your numbers. Constant raises for everyone even if they don't deserve it. Many lazy people just blocking production.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

Always worked overtime because we were understaffed. Pay wasn't worth my time. Always was about sales and never the animals. The only good thing was about the job were my coworkers at the time but after a few started to move on to better opportunities, my time there wasn't long either. Everybody was overworked and underpaid, including the managers.

All about the numbers and they do not care for their staff. They act like they do, but at the end of the day they do not. They cut hours to the bare minimum but expect the same results. Terrible company.
Overall ok place to work. If you are looking for long term with ways to move up you should go somewhere else. In a pinch they will at least give you hours to work.

If you have a love for animals, this is the place to work. I truly enjoyed working with the animals and getting to take care of them. Most of the associates strive for a good working environment and to provide the best care for the animals and the customers. The management in Twin Falls, Idaho is not the best, but is not terrible. Some management cares for its employees and other management can be toxic. The other downfalls to the positions at Petsmart is the pay and hours. I always strive to provide the best customer service and quality work. After a year of continuously asking for a pay raise or to become a full-time employee instead of part-time, nothing ever changed except for an increased work load. Now that I have quit my position there, I am making a better wage with less physical labor.
Good company. Very busy pace. Lots of perks always complimenting you on good job. Safety conscious. Fair pay and ability to make a bonus check. Lots of OT
Overworked and underpaid, mistreated and talked down to, makes you miserable and unhappy, feels like you are spending every second of your time for no reward.
Constantly understaffed and extremely rude customers during rush hour times with no help from management. Very exhausting and constantly overworked. Doggie day camp worse job I ever had.

It was a great experience if you like working with animals and customer service. It's sad when you have to take care of sick animals because there's a 50% chance they can pass away even though they are treated by their own vet. you have to be strong willed to take care of these sick animals, otherwise emotions can get over you. I was a Pet Care Specialist and I love this job but the pay is what is low for all that I did, the rest was good from my 2 managers to the other peers. I  had a great time.
The team was nice and working with animals is great but overall management was below average. Only one person stood out as caring while the rest were no help at all.

I enjoyed my time with PetSmart. As my first job it helped me grow my skills in the animal field and laid down the building blocks for my own personal growth. The quality of your management team will greatly determine how much you like working here. Some managers do not care about the animals in their care.
PetSmart offers great service along with great product and care.  The company goals and policies are fair and easily understood.  PetSmart takes care of their employees as well as the community.
It was okay. Not paid enough for the amount of work required. That’s most places now though. The customers were great though. It did not feel team friendly.

I loved what I did but the drama was unbearable. Being a bather the groomers treat you like dirt and make your workload harder on purpose. When I talked to my coworkers about it the girls said it’s different when you become a groomer...  They completely work you to death and take advantage. Maybe I just had a bad location, but I wouldn’t recommend working as a bather.
Was a fun place to work when dealing with all the animals, but the pay isn’t enough. Good job for a part time of college student who is in need of flexible hours, but should pay more.
I loved working with animals and dealing with customers. Manager is usually flexible when you want a different schedule, so that's nice. Had like 2 days off a week.

This is a good job for a teenager. Management has it's clicks and you have to be in that click to advance.  It's good for a starter job and experience but after you get that, move on. Pay is terrible.
management is a joke, pay is a joke. hours typically sucked. coworkers were usually cool since we all love animals. if you love animals and need a part time job this is for you

Benefits were great upper management not so much great pay a week paid vacation plus sick days unachievable expectations from corporate task management not understood at higher level not enough associates working

A typical day at work was busy and stressful. The only enjoyable part was interacting with the store animals and customer's pets. It's decent for a first job, but the managers/customers can take a toll on your mental health sometimes.

There is so much emphasis on making plan that the employees are worked into the ground.  Coworkers were great and management tries their best but nothing can meet the high standards that corporate puts onto them!

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.
very simple cashier job. Customers are the toughest. management is ok. the most enjoyable part is being able to see all of the animals come into the store.

Don’t become a dog groomer. It’s a miserable career with zero advancement-that goes for almost all grooming jobs, everywhere. Little to no benefits and never get a raise because you are paid commission.

This position (pets hotel associate) is great. It can seem overwhelming at first but you get into this little groove and know everything like the back of your hand in no time. It is so much more than interacting with animals though. It’s fast paced, can be very chaotic during peak hours/days and yea, it’s still retail. You will be dealing with pet parents just as frequently, if not more than animals! I think it can be a lot for teenagers/young adults (the main draw to this sort of job) to handle sometimes... But it makes for good learning experiences. As with any company management varies store to store but everyone at my location is awesome. :)

I was hired for the weekend shift, 3 12 hour shifts. Due to Covid they enforce everyone to work 60 hours every week. This destroyed the work/ life balance and caused issues in my schooling. They could’ve prioritize essential products such as food and medicine instead of toys and holiday products instead of overworking every employee.
I love it! Great hours and animals. People were nice. I love all the new animals. Very chilled. They had a great grooming service there. Never saw anything bad.

Very fun to work here, but sometimes the communication between managers is not good, and you will get in trouble for doing what one manager says and not the other. You really need to listen to the head manager, if another one asks you to do something contradictory to the leader, tell them so as not to get into senseless trouble

Team is awesome.  Managers care about their staff and the pets they sell in the building. Sometimes we are not given the hours needed to do the job they ask from corporate.  Corporate needs to work in stores for a week to see the real daily activities

I think it depends mostly on your store, I had some great mangers/employees, but also bad ones. There is a lot of focus on meeting certain metrics and some days you feel understaffed, especially when closing.

I left because the new person who got promoted was too much of a mean person she was all about getting you into trouble so she could look good at her new position and get her friends in the job.So I left plus I felt really bad at how locked up the dogs would-be for months even.id never leave my dog at a place like that,they don't even get to go outside like ever thats torture especially those that are left by their owners there..it's really sad.

I enjoyed working in the Pet Hotel even though it could get crazy. We had a great team! Store management was poor and a revolving door. Store managers were not trained for Pet Hotel so they were never any help.

After working at my location for 7 months I did not trust petsmart to look after my dog. While at the Petshotel people paid for their dogs to have private 15-30 min playdates and we only have them 12-15 no matter what. (Grooming was aways lovely though)

Started with bad original lead and management  and got sent to grooming academy unprepared. Came back to a new salon lead and is getting better.  It can be physically exhausting, as well as mentally. You must have patience and enjoy being around dogs. The pay in the salon is not good until you finish most of the training after their grooming academy.
It has its ups and downs. Like any job. You can bring your dog here which is nice. Pay is not enough though. The call volume can be overwhelming and the systems feel very outdated.

You learn a lot about petcare but it’s just another corporation out there to make money. Not so great benefits other than product discounts but the overall discount is sad. Stressful and dirty. The company should stop selling fish and small animals as the facilities are lingering with disease and disrepair.

Even though I was only here for a short time. I LOVED EVERY SINGLE DAY OF MY JOB! I was sad to leave. However I am happy for the opportunity to have the experiences. I learned so much in the short time, and I will cherish my time with the salon staff and memories we made forever.

I spent almost two years with PetSmart and hated every second of it. Management is terrible, you have to beg to take a 30 minute break after working for 10 hours straight. The way they treat animals is horrendous. I never want to work there again nor do I want to shop there.
How is this company still open? This was the worse job I ever had. They don’t train properly they don’t treat pets properly they over work pay is horrid. They have poor ethics with animals.
Loved working with the animals and adopting them out to good homes. Management was good and employees were very kind. Some annoying costumers but that's to be expected.

The management team at Lynnwood store is a do as I say, not as I do group. Most staff do not care about the welfare of animals, they are viewed as dollar signs and not a viable little life. The fish are ##constantly infected. Safety and sanitation procedures are not followed. Most staff are unprofessional behind the backs of eachother and customers. Young staff play on their phones constantly and do not like to be told what to do. They need a safe space to pout when they do not get their way. Management will write off store products from the shelves like can dog or cat food, then demand with consequences the staff solicit customers for cash or food donations.. Management talk behind the backs of staff and turn one against another.
This job tends to rely highly on if management is good. The schedule can be flexible and there's some good dogs, but those are the only pros.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

Worked as a pet care specialist mostly playing with dogs all day. Day camp is from 9-5 with an hour break from 12-1. You will mainly be in camp when you first start but once you get the hang of it you’ll be out of camp cleaning, preparing lunches or dinners, and helping the front staff.
It was too long ago to remember properly. I said that this was too long ago to properly remember, however the supervisor and management were hugely underqualified and had no interpersonal skills.
Back in the day, knowing ALL departments was a HUGE help; filling in when short staffed.

Employees are trained to know all areas of the store entirely too fast.  This job would have been way less stressful if they trained an employee in one for department a week or two before moving on to the next.

Sometimes rewarding. The amount of work that is to be done in the petcare department is not worth the pay.  There’s a lot of tasks to be done in a short amount of time while also having to help customers almost always on your own.
I worked here for over 2 years and loved it, it was fun and I got along with everyone great. If I could have had. amore family oriented schedule i would have stayed

Pay is awful unless you're a groomer or manager. You get passed over for promotions and the pay raises are a joke. They'll often schedule you to work closing and opening shifts and will take advantage of you whenever possible.

The work itself was fun, but the management was horrendous. Every month we would get a new manager in the store with new expectations. I was practically bullied out of my position and job in general. My coworkers were some of the best people I have ever met, but the management needs serious work.

Not sure if it's just my location but there was very poor management. Overall, everyone was nice but most of the time the store was on fire. Not to mention there wasn't enough compensation for all the work you're doing.

The management and HR are HORRIBLE. They only care about what work is getting done. They also are really bad liars and manipulaters. They will fire you for using the time you have to go home wether if it’s for being sick or emergencies. Anything.
Petsmart only cares about money and forcing you to overwork yourself. They need to get their corporate people off the backs of the stores...and they don't care about you during this pandemic.
learning to groom at Petsmart was ok. Nothing special. Learned the basics and safety protocols. Benefits were decent. They constantly asked you to do more and groom more.
I loved working here. Great managers and enjoyable work. There is a positive atmosphere because people love their pets. Management worked with me and gave me good opportunities.

The best part about working for this company was working with animals and building relationships with co-workers and pet parents. The company itself does not care or value you and make it very clear that you are replaceable, regardless of how hard you work. They are an insatiable company and never recognize accomplishments, only criticize the things that can be done "better," or the things that you did "wrong."

you’ll never be fully compensated for your work. petsmart is a selfish company that only cares about money. i worked in the store and in the salon and the ONLY good thing about the job were my regular clients (the dogs specifically because most of the customers were rude) and my fellow salon associates. i was treated horribly by core management and never received any support. A coworker of mine got really sick and couldn’t come into work (before covid) and they demoted her from being a groomer because of it. They only care about themselves. Don’t waste your time

I will start off with, PetSmart has always been this much of a mess, this has not changed due to the recent pandemic. My store had new management very frequently and could not keep employees because of unfair expectations for employees not scheduled to work. If you did not come in when they called, you would be punished. The managers would often fight amongst themselves and pit lower employees against each other. Departments were poorly managed, never maintained properly, and safely regulations were completely ignored. I had to do several safety walks and was told by higher ups to falsify monthly safety inspections for store performance.

I enjoyed my time on the front end as a cashier, especially seeing people bring their pets into the store. I learned a lot about different animal care in my five years there, and I eventually was cross trained as a receptionist in the salon. I loved being a salon receptionist, and it inspired me to eventually switch careers and focus on admin positions as a specialty. The customers and pets were the best part of this job. The schedule unfortunately fluctuated wildly from week to week, and the management was a mixed bag. Some of them were amazing, and others were petty and small-minded.

I couldn't complain about pay or benefits. The overall job I enjoyed. The customers and routine wasn't bad. Computer systems completely outdated, EXTREME issues with management, training non existent, daily and weekly goals, though obtainable were placing heavy burdens on a single person, and again, upper management was horrible. I ended up quitting upset and furious and in turn was accused of stealing and banned from ever working for Petsmart again.  And it was truly upsetting because I worked hard and gave it my all only to be treated badly, mainly because I was female. Even though it was almost all women in the store.. except for the store manager

Because it's not a super huge store it was a pretty easy job for stocking. We had our time in the morning before the store opened to pack out the truck, which was nice and uninterrupted. It was also a big plus having people like you, with a love for animals, to work with too.

I liked my job here until I got laid off because of COVID. I’d still be working there otherwise. My boss was very supportive and the people I worked with were great and friendly people. I pretty much worked side by side with the inventory leader to replenish the store. Got to wear my headphones, lots of independence when I wanted it and support when I needed it. But that’s all a tribute to my managers!

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

A lot of people believe that working with dogs is all fun and games, but it’s not. A lot of the time you’re in the salon, they’re are going to be dogs that are scared, it’s happens. They could be unsocialized or have had a bad experience at the groomers. You have to be comfortable holding dogs, grinding nails, etc. It’s a very rewarding job and I wouldn’t change my job for anything in the world, I absolutely love bathing pups, but it isn’t for everyone. I need to me patient and confident, especially since dogs can tell when your nervous. I would recommend this job to anyone who really wants to work with dogs, but it’s not the easiest job in the world.

Worked here for three years. Gained experience here that I needed. Honestly, management makes or breaks the job itself. First two years loved my managers and enjoyed coming to work, last year on the job with new management made it horrible and many people quit. They make it easy to be able to work in different departments or move up, pay is not great and the raises aren’t great either. It is stable though and especially if it’s your first job. It’s retail mixed with animal care depending on the department you work in. Get to see cute animals  :)

Horrible work environment in the salon. They do nothing but talk about you and belittle you. There are definitely favorites among the manager and certain groomers who are allowed to do whatever they want to. It's like being in high school all over again. They never follow rules but expect you to follow them otherwise you get into trouble. When you talk to management, they do nothing and it only makes the situation worse.
Department management is great, store manager was often hiding in the office and not involved with running the store. Learned a lot and enjoyed my time here.
Coworkers were nice and management was alright. There were barely any hours though and they didn't gave us hazard pay; other places were paying $2 more during the pandemic.

I worked under a management team that was very good. I've heard stories of other locations having bad management, so that can vary from store to store. Overall, I learned a lot about animals working there, whether it be from my own research or from the (nice) customers that came in. I had a really good experience at PetSmart, but I never really got the chance to advance my career there.

You take the good with the bad here, I guess. Depending on your size and experience this may not be a hard job at all, but as a 90 lb person thats probably one of the first words I’d use to describe my job. That or frustrating.

It was nice working here.  I worked in several different locations in different states over the years.  Every salon is very different. I worked under several very good managers and one absolutely insane store.  PetSmart tries to care about it's groomers but that can be lost when management wants you to continue working on an aggressive dog to meet the sales quota.
Customer care of the animals is a lot of work and they should pay more. Easy going place to work. Management is great with working around your schedule, so its great job for students.

A terrible company filled with upper management that was borderline evil. It's almost like it was a requirement to work there. After they were sold, all they cared about was cutting hours and overworking their staff.

After working here for about 6 months as a bather, I had to leave there were no real educators to teach how to properly bathe a dog and the leadership was very all over the place. We didn't have a manager and on top of that, the groomers would be rude and force the bathers to do stuff that didn't want to do.

I was an early morning stocker, which meant I worked with two other people to fully download the trucks. Problem is, management does not understand how quickly you are able to download the trucks and fully put out all the product. They have a 'math equation' to measure how long it should take you, but it is almost always off. Even if you are moving no-stop, knocking out carts left and right, you will always end up with one additional pallet that you just couldn't get to.

The company itself isn’t too bad. It’s the management in the store that will make or break the experience you have there. With the store I was at, management only ever cared about their favorites and numbers. They were horrible with scheduling with school, would talk bad behind your back over simple things and will act rude and disrespectful if you have family issues going on. Most of the positions are part time so never go in expecting to get 20 or more hours a week.

Petsmart only cares about making money they don’t care about the mental or physical health of their employees or their animals for that matter. I would recommend not working at PetSmart unless you enjoy getting paid Bologna  money to do crazy amounts of job responsibilities.
didnt expect people ro be unprofessional. store was clean at least. i had less hours over time. they do run a background check and no they dont drug test. but could be different for each interviewee.

Don’t stay here long. In all locations I worked at, favoritism and cliques run rampant and unchecked. Managers often cover their own mistakes and laziness by assigning huge amounts of work to unqualified departments and guilt newer employees into staying for longer shifts or coming in early/on days off. There’s a highschool level of hazing that happens within management and senior employees. If you aren’t immediately well-liked by the upper crust, you find yourself getting assigned janitorial roles — cleaning up all of the pet accidents, taking care of food spills, cleaning restrooms — and nonstop register shifts for 9 hours. Your shifts will consist of the least-liked managers and the least-reliable employees. If you’re well-liked immediately, you’ll find yourself getting pulled into the office for snacks, given advancement opportunities before they are posted publicly and offered more desirable shifts with more efficient coworkers. Advancement opportunities are extremely difficult to get unless all of management likes you, which often means answering phone calls on your days off and doing things that are way above your pay grade for no extra compensation. Employees are promptly thrown under the bus for any mistakes management or other departments make. I witnessed several coworkers get mocked or told they were lying during traumatic events such as illness, family/pet death, and accidents/injury that occurred outside of work. You don’t get paid enough for this.

Upon arrival at Petsmart, I admit it was alot to digest. Started as part of the management team. Which has been a blessing. Learning things as you grow. Management team is supportive. Corporate is supportive, as well as, DM. Happy to be a part of the team at Petsmart. Every day is an adventure. Enjoy working with the public, assisting with their pet needs.

As a groomer, in my opinion you are paid well.  It's really based on what level of stress u can handle. You can groom 5-6 pups a day and it's breezy or you can do 8-10 dogs a day and feel the pressure. But don't think u are there to JUST groom. You will also be cleaning, answering phones, walk-ins, bringing dogs in and out and depending on management... they can be annoying....but that's their job. It's a great stepping stone into the grooming world.

There are many things that are performed that anyone with proper animal care knowledge knows are not in the best interest of the animals. Many of the managers don’t have knowledge or experience with 90% of their he animals being sold. Most small animals and fish come from pet farms so they come in sick.
Management

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

Working here is fun and never boring. Lots of different dogs every day so there is always something to learn. Depending on how busy the salon is, it can get a bit crazy at times so you've got to be up and running at all times.
Definitely a good place to work for those starting out in retail. Working in Petcare was extremely fun and you learn so much about the animals you sell!

I worked at the petshotel for 6 months and I LOVED my job. The only reason I quit was because I was working overnights and my mental health declined. If I could get a job there during the day, I'd be happy.

Working here was fun and a good first job, but only managers get anywhere around full-time. Part-time workers are worked very little and do just about every duty in the store for only minimum wage. And managers are paid barely above minimum. Overall, it's just a place to get some experience before moving on to a better opportunity.

PetSmart is a great example of a big corporation that exploits their workers. Most stores hire people at just under the full time requirement so that they'll have you there every day but you do not get benefits. You are going to get minimum wage, and often times the store is so understaffed that you will be guilted into not taking your breaks. The most frustrating part about PetSmart is the way they are handling COVID. The sanitation rules are not enforced and if you get COVID, there is little to no help offered to you.

Company used to be great to work for but over the past couple of years has really gone downhill. Corporate doesn't provide enough hours to properly run the store or take care of the animals. Ever since covid started I have not felt safe at my job because we are not allowed to enforce the mask mandate
It is a great place to start to work however it is retail and all the company care about is sales. Customers were awful and dealing with them was horrendous.

This was one of my favorite jobs I’ve worked, my coworkers and management were pretty cool and seeing animals everyday made it fun. Although you don’t get raises very often and there’s not much of advancement, you get an employee discount and they are flexible with schedules. Working here while going to school was great, they have a tuition reimbursement program & they pay you after a semester if you pass. The only thing that sucked was the crazy cat ladies that came in and complained about things you couldn’t change/do.
Overworked. No hours. The store leadership is doing the roles of cashier and stocker. Used to love it. Now looking elsewhere.

In the beginning I really enjoyed my time at this job. As I spent more time there, however, I began to see it for what it really is... a money-hungry corporation just looking to make the most cheese any way possible. Over the years our salon staff started to dwindle under constant lack of competent management. They were constantly hiring unqualified people for the job, failing to train them properly, and then would be surprised when we had terrible feedback from customers. After COVID hit it only got worse. They expected us to do our regular amount of work and then some to make up for the other salon members that had left for various reasons - all while hearing from store management that they couldn’t help us because they were just ‘too busy’ out on the floor. Nevermind that when we had a salon worker test positive for the virus, they did ABSOLUTELY NOTHING in response. They didn’t close the salon, they didn’t sanitize overnight, nothing - nada, zero, zip, zilch. Every single person in the salon was so unhappy, yet none wanted to leave, mostly because of their benefits package which is about the only reason worth staying for this company.

Days are long, constantly pulled away from the dog you're working on to answer phones or do a walk in nail trim. upper management pushes more dogs into your schedule so you're constantly behind. management does not help you stay on track.
Flexible and beneficial great company to work for definitely recommend it as a first time job but don’t plan or expect to move up in the company with change due

A someone who had no experience grooming or bathing dogs when i was hired, I learned a lot and enjoyed working with the animals everyday. There was room for growth to advance to a Groomer position, which was nice

I work with them for over a year. When I first came in they were all very sweet but within a month the management totally changed and went down hill from there. Management is what made me give this job such a low score. The job is VERY enjoying if you love animals and know how to handle. The management team picked favorites and broke a good few rules as well. basically turned into high school drama. They DID NOT CARE for the employees when they had personal problems and would talk badly behind your back. Very selfish and it got to a point where the head store manager didn’t fix anything that 2 managers in the hotel left due to unfairness and favoritism. I would not work here personally and would not recommend
A lot of turn over with people starting with higher pay doing less then you. It’s a job don’t plan on staying for a long period because you won’t make anything more but .20

I got hired as an early morning stocker and was told I would work 4am-12pm most days and get out at 8am other days. During the short time I worked here, they had me on register 99% of the time even though I told them I don’t want to be a cashier and I was hired as a stocker. And then after I got back from vacation they drastically cut everyone’s hours. Mine was down to 5 hours a week. That’s when I said peace I’m out. It’s nice getting a paycheck weekly and the job isn’t high responsibility but management is very poor at this location and no one communicates with each other
Fun job, good hours. I worked here in my early 20’s. I think it’s a great job for any one who needs to earn some money while still having a flexible schedule. Learned a lot about pet care.

PetSmart is one of the leaders in pet retail but it’s very fast oriented. Understated and you have to make the decision of sacrificing customer service for tasks that sometimes have no impact on the store.

This store is an absolute train wreck. I worked there for a couple years and throughout the time I was there, my job role got bounced around, had a ton of turnover, bunch of new managers and more. Some managers were great, others were so incompetent it would have been laughable had I not been totally messed over all the time. I only worked the job I was hired as for like 6 months before they changed my job role with no notice, explanation or reason whatsoever. Store lead had no care or concern for availability of associates or when asked why job role was changed. Also, they do not care about the safety of the animals whatsoever. Sick animal? Shove it in quarantine until they eventually die. They rarely ever had actual vet visits and many animals could have survived had they seen a vet and weren't just shoved in the quarantine sick room. Tiny Tales cages are death traps and yet they promote them. So much wrong.
Typical retail job with wonky hours and low pay rate, but overall decent job to have. I don't have the patience to work retail long term... but it wasn't the worst place

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.
If you've worked any other retail job you have an idea what to expect. The only twist is the pet focused nature of the company, so you do have opportunities to mess with cute animals each day.
I had a good job there but I had to leave due to my hands getting an allergic reaction. All my coworkers were nice and I had the same customers every week so it was fun to see the same faces.
Leadership team seems to only believe one side of a story when someone reports another associate. They will not help an associate.

Each Petsmart is either great or terrible depending on the management. At Petsmart in Peru when I worked there was pretty great! The store manager was very nice and willing to help me succeed and teach me. The pay at petsmart wasn't great as it is a corporate company.

I was a pet stylist apprentice. The only training you receive is videos that are about a minute long. I’ve never trimmed a dogs nails before and the only training I got was a 30 second clip of someone trimming nails and it was the worse angle and not even zoomed in. They need more hands on training!! They show you everything in the videos, then you’re expected to just jump in and do it and be comfortable the first time though. Videos don’t account for squirmy dogs, aggressive dogs, or anything else that might happen. I wouldn’t let a hairstylist cut and style my hair if she only learned through videos, so why are we allowing people to bathe and groom dogs without hands on training and practice?!! Ever since I started I knew it wasn’t going to work. I was always scheduled 5 hour shifts and received no break because of it. The only people who got breaks were those who worked 6 or more hours which is why I was conveniently scheduled 5 5 hour shifts a week. I had to go to the bathroom to even get a sip of water. The pay is terrible. You only make decent money if you’re a groomer who’s always booked up. Don’t work in the salon unless you plan on waiting over a year to become a stylist and another year to actually get clients and make good money.
Pay could be better, but overall it was a good place to get started in retail and customer service. Too much is expected from the pet care department for too little pay.

The company is great to work for to start grooming as long as you don’t mind a two year contract. You will be trained with the company to groom breed standards and safety. Long term- you are expected to work nights and almost every weekend (Friday, Saturday, and Sunday.) The company is very pushy on up selling people and numbers (including how many grooms you do in a day) so if you’re numbers aren’t up to par, expect to be talked to or potentially written up. Overall when I started with the company it was great, they were bought out by another company since then which has been known to flip businesses into being more profitable. Expect to feel like a number in a corporation.

I was a dog trainer at petsmart, the only trainer in the store, and while I loved the training aspect of my job, I was treated as an associate that *sometimes* had training (I had A LOT of training stuff to do) and management would get upset when I was too busy to help them around the store. I could never be sick because I didn't have anyone to cover my classes so I would have to work while ill.
I can go on and on about this company but won’t.

A typical day at work was stressful. Working in Pet Care is pretty much you coming in and assuming nothing has been done. It was never a team effort working here, even though that was the only way to be successful. Management was trash. The managers would only respond if they HAD to be called on the radio, otherwise they would toss up who has to leave the office. The scheduling problem was a whole issue within itself, never was posted on time until one of the store managers got reported than they finally started making it weeks ahead. Any "enjoyable" part of the job was the animals when they weren't coming in with infections. You only get a 15% discount so it really isn't anything to write home about. From the managers not wanting to take a dying snake to the hospital to never making the schedule on time, this is a job I wouldn't reccommend to my worst enemy.

Great place to work!  Yes there are some annoying customers, but that is everywhere.  Managers tend to stay in place too long which prevents opportunities for advancement.  Pay opportunities are great as you move up.

The company was wonderful to work for until it was bought by BC Partners. Once it went private, making a profit was all that mattered. Communication became unorganized, corporate people came and left the company constantly, and the family feeling disappeared. Manager pay was decent, associate pay not so much. And once Covid hit, things went downhill even more. The company was slow to respond to safety measures and laid off its cleaning people (at a time when sanitation was of the utmost importance), then came down on the stores about their cleanliness! The company also reduced associate hours w the expectation that the salaried store managers would make up the difference. They did not give hazard pay to anyone, but did take away the manager and associate annual increases to pay out a "thank you" bonus to associates (giving nothing to managers).

Like many of the other reviews about PetSmart I also have seen a decline in the company over the years. I was with the company from the end of 2017 to the summer of 2020 but I've heard it started getting bad about 5+ years ago. Corporate doesn't care about the employees or animals. After covid hit they fired most of the staff and put all the work on a couple employees and managers. There were times where it'd be just me and a cashier for an 8+ hour shift. They cut more and more people but expect more work to be done. Trucks from weeks prior will still be in the back needing to be worked because we wouldn't have enough staff to run the store and fill. It also got to a point where morning petcare duties would be crammed into the night duties as well so they would only have to have one person come in for the day but that meant that sick animals would miss medications and of course not all the work could be done by one person in a shift while also dealing with customers/checkout/curbside/phones and whatever else. The company has surpassed sales goals for months during covid but refuse to hire employees back because they see how much more money they can make by having less staff. It was a weight off my shoulders to quit from this company.

they started changing the schedule after covid where you are in petcare 8 to 1230 lunch is 1230 to 1 then you are cashier until you leave. absolutely caused alot of issues with the care and up keep of the animals. amazing team

Overworked, managers will lie to you to get what they want, and not every location takes great care of their animals. Some of them do, but it really depends. They say they want all of their employees that can be to be cross trained, but not all of them make time for it.

My job at PetSmart was a lot of fun. I really loved getting to interact with a lot of different dog breeds and people. My absolute favorite part was when we had puppies come in and I got to bathe and play with the puppies. Working in the salon is a lot of hard work though, especially as a bather. While you may be overbooked with a ton of dog breeds (some that take more than the usual 2 hour maximum allowed bath time, like malamutes or other large, thick-furred breeds) you still have to take every walk-in nails appointment or walk-in bath appointments. On weekends, it can be incredibly overwhelming, and there would be times I would be stressed to tears. It's also a really active job, so if you're not okay with a lot of moving around, bending over for long periods of time, and lifting heavy puppies, it might not be a good fit for you. The back was also really wet and cold so I got sick with a cold often. But having those clients that would come back to see you and getting to know each dog well, and have them excited to come back to see you, was a feeling I really couldn't replace. I would go home every night stinky and smelling like dog and covered in fur though. I loved my coworkers and we would all get along so great, joking and laughing and helping each other take care of dogs. I did appreciate how my salon manager worked with me and made sure I was okay and helped me whenever I needed help. She really made the job a lot less stressful. And as for moving up, you can either choose to stay a bather or go to Grooming School to become a groomer, so it's entirely up to you how you

There was always some drama going on through the work days. You couldn’t call out sick at all unless you wanted to have the managers act funny towards you for weeks after. And the management also doesn’t help as much as you’d expect them to they just sit in there office all day.

Low pay for management position, many OSHA violations, lack of training, outdated systems, but the store employee culture was nice. Meeting people's pets makes it a different kind of customer service job.
Was a great place to work, wish i didn't work so far so i could continue working there. Management was very good in regards to worklife/balance

Petsmart is a great place to work the employees their are always helpful if you can't do a dog by yourself they are more than willing to help you. They try everything in their power to get the dog done. Meetings are about what everyone could do better not just what we are doing wrong. They love focusing on the things we are doing correctly.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

It felt really good helping the animals quality of life, and helping the pet parents improve the quality of their pets' lives as well. I learned a lot of new things, and met some really nice people, and it felt good being needed, since I was the only cross trained employee at the time of my employment, so I would work a shift being a cashier, and then work a shift doing pet care, a lot of the time in the same shift, or back to back

Production often fluctuates and they sometimes require your to work longer than the times you were orginially scheduled for. I appreciate they feel bad, but it is a lot for some people to work almost 50-60 hours a week when you signed up for 40.
Work-life balance
Set boundaries for yourself, don't let there be grey area in terms of what you're comfortable doing cause you will end up doing it. Days become pretty routine depending on what you are doing.
It was cool and calming. Could be stressful at times but what job isn't. The people I worked with were all cool and helped a lot. The animals are super cool. All in all good place.
Management

You meet some great people, but they suck at hiring management, if you get hurt or need emergency assistance the response time is awful. You can work yourself to the bone (even skipping lunches and bathroom breaks) just to be told you are still not doing enough. Corporate barely knows what is going on at the stores they are over. You can work somewhere much less stressful for much more pay.

havent worked here in a while but when i did management sucked, it probably still does. Mostly young kids work here. Dont really care about doing the job, just want to play with animals and talk to their friends. Floor associates are mostly part time, so its not a job for you if you need a steady income.

The dogs are the best part of working at petsmart. I enjoy coming to work and having one on one time with my favorite animals. I like that we aren't allowed to take aggressive pets. It makes work a lot easier.
Work-life balance

Petsmart is a good place to work especially for work experience! I definitely think management could use improvement though. I have very nice coworkers but we are very understaffed... Management doesn't take enough responsibility we always only close with one manager and most times there won't be a manager on the floor to help you when you need or they take very long to come.

Back in the day petsmart was the best place to shop for pets. Since the buy out in 2014/15 the company is going down hill. The associates don't CARE i walk in and I feel like about to get a burrito at moes " welcome to petsmart!!!!" But they don't stop and ask you anything.

The store lead isn't very capable, and the salon is an extremely stressful, toxic place to work. The groomers are so catty and treat the bathers terribly with no consequences from the salon manager. They don't pay you enough to tolerate being treated that way.

One of the best jobs I had, management was awesome and upbeat great at keeping you motivated. Honestly zero complaints, would definitely work here again. They truly care about you and that's hard to find in a job anymore. The best part was being able to interact with the customers and animals on a daily basis.
Communication is key. Management wasn’t always the most helpful and the salon seemed to form cliques, but there were some cool people to talk to. Just never out side of work
Worked as stocker, had to come in at 4. Work was fine, but hours were not great. It is a good part time job for someone in high school or college that needs some quick cash, but can't live off of it.
It was terrible to work for. The manger was rude and the other employees would bully me or be rude towards me for no reason. I refuse to ever go there again. They made me feel so low.
Cool , nice pay , decent benefits. Nice hours , set hours. Overall it was  decent job.  Give it a five out of a 10. Just trying to waste space here...
People are working a lot of hours nowadays. It’s hard to see a light at the end of the tunnel, but at least the pay is good. Paychecks every week and decent benefits
Worked with some good coworkers. Understandable and helpful coworkers. Good environment. Able to work throughout the day. Enjoy working on my shifts.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

Management in salon was horrible. Started with no lead so sent to another store to train with awesome people and leads. Then sent back to store I was to work at which was in Stroudsburg PA. Finally got salon lead who just graduated grooming school come in on a power trip to everyone. When I would ask for help didn't receive it as I was still learning. It got so stressful I did quit. Not to mention how dirty the salon was no one kept up cleaning it all fell on new girl. I started with another girl but she never showed back up. I wonder why till I seen it happening to myself. I was told I'd receive breaks most of them were missed because of work load and no help.

I loved the management team, got to know the returning customers and their pets.  Petsmart is a great place to work and a great place to move up.  Overall petsmart by far was one of my favorite retail jobs I have ever had!
Working in PetSmart is not hard but sometime requires weight lifting. Always fun, every day is different. Managers are very nice with employees. Dealing with animals is very enjoyable.
Work-life balance

I worked here as an early morning stocker, and I absolutely loved my job. My managers were amazing and friendly. They really made sure to let me know I was doing a good job, and made me feel appreciated. 10/10 recommend working here.

I worked here for 5 years, started out as a cashier and worked my way up to Support Manager. Only took about a year and a half. The pay wasn’t so good but I started working there my senior year in high school so they knew they could cheat me in that area.
Watch out.  It may seem like a dream job but you are constantly having to worry about following policy instead of doing what is right/needed for the health and safety of pets.
Work-life balance
It's gone down hill lately, but it's not all bad. The pay is good, the work is hard. Every store is short staffed. You are a number to the company and easily replaced, but lots of chances to move up.

I enjoyed working with animals, learning more about them, and talking about them with other people, but this was overall quite the stressful job. It did involve caring for the animals in the store, but also retail/sales tasks and customer service along with the extensive animal care and cleaning. I often felt very rushed and that I did not have enough time to complete everything that I needed to (before the store opened in the mornings especially). Customers can be extremely rude/mean and can wear you down mentally at times, like any retail job. I was a college student when I worked here, and my managers were always accommodating with my class schedule. Some of the other employees were difficult to work with at times (drama, complaining, gossip, etc.).
Set boundaries for yourself, don't let there be grey area in terms of what you're comfortable doing cause you will end up doing it. Days become pretty routine depending on what you are doing.
it was really fun because management and the employees were super nice. The environment was amazing to work in because everyone was so helpful which made things faster

I have worked at multiple petsmarts and really it all comes down to your managers and coworkers on if you like this job. Because let me tell you, the customers and corporate are horrible. You WILL get many customers who want animals and not give them a good home, if you have a good manager you can say no but a bad manager may be a different story. But a big thing is that Petsmart does NOT care about you outside of work. I was often called in on my days off and guilt tripped if I could not come in and heaven help you if you try to call in sick even with this pandemic going on. I was chewed out horribly for calling in sick several times and once even told I HAD to come in even though I was very ill. To them, you are a work machine who needs to be there for them at any given time.
If you love animals more than humans like I do then this job is perfect for you! My favorite part of working here is getting to see and love on dogs that come in during my shifts..

Petsmart is a great place to work . Career advancement is very easy as long as you put the effort . They truly care about their employees . I started as a Bather and six months later i was sent to grooming school my store director lorena was awesome and taught us all so much she really loves what she does and it shoes with the quality of the store and happiness of pets and pet parents overall the company deserves a 10+ i learned so much from all my leaders .
Love the Pet parents love the ethos and everything that the Company has done for myself in my time with the company. Appreciate the COVID-19 protocols as well. Taken very seriously

Pre covid, I was mostly happy working at Petsmart. There were challenges, but overall we were staffed well. I understand every company is having a hard time coping with covid, but our hours were cut to the point we're unable to give proper care to the animals in our store. I'm basically forced to lie to managment about what I'm doing (ex. saying I'm helping a costumer) to just be able to feed and water all my animals every night. There's little to no concern on a corporate level for the animal's safety or health - they're only treated like merchandise. Animald are dying from subpar care, employees are consistently working off the clock to keep the store afloat, and the hours aren't being brought back even as our revenue has returned to pre covid levels. Oh, we did get a $100 bonus taxed at 50% and a "thank you" pin to wear, so all our costumers know we've been thanked for being essential. Super validating considering theres no cleaning protocol anymore. Pin pads, carts, even bathrooms don't yet cleaned even on a weekly basis now.

Don’t work here. The management is terrible because they expect you to consistently bust your a*s, and make over 100% and when you take a break to breathe or go to the bathroom they hound you for it. Rate was really hard to acquire and when you did make rate they expected more out of you. They say that when you make rate and work for 3 months that you get cross trained in another region, not true. I was there for almost a year and they kept me in the same region, but we’re hiring people straight into the region I wanted to be trained in. Can’t forget to mention that since covid, they’ve mandated every weekend to work for the past 5 or 6 months, and are now forcing people to work 60 hours a week. Their application is all a lie and they are liars because they never once stood behind anything they promised. When I first started working there I had intentions to build a career because I thought it was a great job, but there’s a lot they don’t tell you till your actually there and they treat their employees like slaves, ontop of firing you if you make one mistake. Their turnaround rate is unbelievable, 5 or 6 new people being trained every week. DONT WORK HERE.
Work-life balance

I feel like when people think of being a dog bather, they think its all rainbows and sunshine and you just get to play with puppies all day. It is a tough job and not for everyone. You HAVE to have a passion for dogs and it is pretty physically demanding. But I loved it! My only complaint is I wish you were paid commission per dog instead of hourly.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

I got a job at PetSmart as a Trainer. I was to be sent to a different city for 2 weeks (paid) to learn how to train dogs. I ended up finding out I was pregnant and decided against the 2 week training, and instead took a job as a sales associate.
Management is great even for a Corp. I love the people I work with. ESP in the salon there is a sense of family. Everyone is very close and supportive.

Although I loved working at Petsmart, I was underpaid and under appreciated. Nice to your face and then mistreat you with their actions. Being a sales associate means being bored most of your shift if you aren’t given tasks or have customers coming in.
Fun but unorganized place to work. They do not put employees first. They do not help with growth and development and the management is not engaged with the employees.
Excellent management that cares about your success.  For example, if there is something you don't understand they are very willing to help you understand.

Petsmart is ok for a part time job for extra money and that’s about it. When I started working there I wanted to pursue a career as a dog groomer, I was constantly given the run around from management and I decided to quit, best decision I made and I don’t regret it.

I was so excited to work at PetSmart, and from day one, I felt unwelcome. It was confusing to be hired for my skills and experience, only to be treated like an idiot constantly by my manager. There was a group in our department that included a lot of leadership who had been friends for years, and they all just raved about each other's work and ignored anyone not in the in group.

A long time ago this company was really good but alot has changed. Really depends on store leader some are good,  mine only cares about their ego and their standing and not about their employees. Working there leaves you with a case of PTSD.

By far one of the worst places I’ve ever worked. They promise you training as a groomer after two years but they will delay it if they don’t have someone competent in your position. Black mold was growing in the bathing room but management refused to acknowledge it and just pained over it. The paint used took 24 hrs to dry but management refused to allow it to cure, saying the salon couldn’t be closed even a day, and dogs went home shaved because we couldn’t get the paint off them. Banfield attached  to us didn’t care about the welfare of animals in our care, allowing pets to suffer so they could close early or so that they didn’t have to deal with it. I’d only accept a position here is you don’t care about animals and are okay with apathetic management.

This location lacks the fair treatment to it's employees. The pay is poor and managers are expected to complete more job assignments than they were originally assigned at the time of hire. Hours change sporadically and with very short notice, or none at all. Certain coworkers are favorited. Overall a very disappointing workplace.

Working at petsmart was by far the worst experience of my life. The management would purposefully get in the way of you doing your job and then berate you for doing poorly. Coworkers refused to care for animals correctly: over a dozen animals died in the time I worked there from being improperly medicated or straight up dehydrated to death. Those were just the ones I found myself. Company requires employees to feed an incorrect diet to animals to save costs, to the point of causing medical issues due to lack of nutrients.

Started off as a seasonal cashier and I absolutely hated it. I never have experienced worse anxiety in my life than on the register. After months and months and almost a year working there, I was finally moved departments (pet care). I was much happier. Although I do not agree with most of the protocol and animal care rules that we had to abide by, working with animals was fun and my team and coworkers were great.

I was in the Petcare department and occasionally on register. I loved being in petcare. Lots of flexibility in hours and your focus doesnt always have to be on customer service but instead on animal care and safety.

I worked here all through getting my bachelors degree and they were always very understanding about my changing schedules. Everyone was lovely to work with and the environment is great. Only thing is it is a retail job, so dealing with bad customers can be a downside.

Working with the animals is fun and a big stress reliever if you work at a slower store. When you are hired, you are not given much information on how to care for animals, but are taught how corporate wants you to care for the animals when they are in the store (which is not good for long term). Unfortunately at all locations many customers get defensive if you try to educate them on what the proper animal care for each animal is. If you work in the petcare department as an opener, the main tasks are cleaning animal enclosures, which is great if you enjoy cleaning. Petcare closers clean a bit, check on the animals, and do anything else that needs catching up on. If you work as a cashier, get ready to put on a smile and be tethered to the register for most of your shift while also being expected to stock, grab carts, check online orders, greet everyone, etc. Email capture and having customers enrolled for the rewards system is a big deal, and so is selling a certain amount of puppy guides every week. Of course, some locations are not as pushy about it as others. I do not recommend working at a petsmart that is large and busy on the weekends, as all of that traffic will be on you, the one cashier, and the single manager that got scheduled for that day. Many (if not all) stores are not given enough hours to schedule employees so that all customers can be helped in a timely manner, so many times it's just you and two other employees.

It is always something new every day that I like or don't like. it would be hard to get the time off that I need to take off. My bosses were nice but they didn't ever hire enough people so we would be working full time as I am a part time employee while in school.

Below average management, last minute scheduling, did not take covid seriously, managers are rude, they also leave the cashiers with bling lines while gossiping in the cash room. Lack of training, they kinda just throw you out there and get annoyed when you ask questions. Their animals they’d eat basically come from the equivalent of puppy mills, most die upon arrival, they’re also unethical with how they keep the pets and they info they give out

Your not paid well to start. The managers do not care about you and you are expected to know/do more than whats required of your actual job. They give you very little training. Yelled at if you miss your lunch or work over time but over schedule you and make it difficult to take a lunch break or leave on time.
lot of work for barely any pay; management expects too much with very little resources. cover up a lot of bad things that happen, especially in doggie day camps/grooming.
Work-life balance

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.
Overall
Management has been super flexible to work around my full-time job and family life schedule. Wish it paid more however, for the flexibility I need, this will be fine for a side hustle.
I enjoyed it because it was exactly what you would expect from this type of job. I learned a lot and it was fun to be in that environment. Overall, I enjoyed the job itself.

This company traumatized me mentally because during one of my shifts at the Secaucus PetSmart a dog was ripped apart in the PetSmart pets hotel I've had to go to therapy for years to try and get over it I can't even go into PetSmarts anymore.
This company does not appreciate you. The management is horrible. Please do not waste your time working here because you will not be appreciated  for all that you do.
It was a good job. I was a cashier and the employees were really nice. The customers were good. The hours weren't too bad and I usually could get time off if I needed it.
during my time with this company there were many issues handled incorrectly by management. Job advancement was particularly difficult as there was little effort to develop staff for promotion.
Pay & benefits

Management had crazy turnover. The customers were always squirrelly but if you have okay coworkers, it's your basic retail job. Demanding of energy and pretty draining but it's not a bad gig for a high schooler etc.
I had fun working at Petsmart but as a cashier your pressured to get email addresses from customers some had no problem giving me there email others wouldn’t give cause they knew they would bombarded
Pay & benefits
decent first job or getting your feet wet. Poor hours but easy job for the most part. Happy i started my career at petsmart. They were kind enough to give me a shot.

The store manager is important as he/she determines how well the store will be run. My store manager truly had an open door and was always willing to assist/listen. I cannot say enough good things about him! (He is no longer at my store as they switch store managers around a lot.) I have fond memories of my time at PetSmart. I was a Support Manager for several years.

The store I worked at was a smaller one, and from what I gathered via word of mouth from staff at other locations, our store was more laid back than others in the same district. The managers were fairly easy-going, the starting pay was higher than I'd anticipated, and best of all, the schedule was very flexible in my favor. Of the several large retail chains I've worked for over many years, this was one of the better experiences overall.
Show up to work at your scheduled shift (6-2 or 1-9). Feed and water all animals, give medications to sick animals, tend to cats in adoption room, clean fishtanks, bag fish or crickets for customers.

I liked working with the animals, but there was soooo much to do and no time to do it all, considering we were expected to help out with customer service half the time. I wish they would revamp the system and just hire more people.

Without getting into detail I was witnesses to multiple harassment incidents. I reported them to cooperate HR and they chose to separate with me. I don't think anything happened to the perpetrator in question or management for that matter.

To be honest Management isn't the best to associates. Theres definitely 'Classes' in which you can't be friends with anyone above you in which I was literally told "You can only hang out with people on your level." Also favoritism is very obviously ruled in when it comes to promitions. Managers can talk down to you and are kinda mean. They could probably bully and call you names and upper managers still use excuses about them being stressed. Also be prepared to take on some of the extra Managers work that their probably gonna put on you and make the excuse that their busy. I've never felt more disposable then I do here. They take advantage of others looking to work with animals and treat you poorly.
The people I worked with cared about animals, we were just a bit overworked for the small amount we were paid. Overall though it's a good place to start if you want a career with animals
Good to learn basics about customer service, lots of drama though. Very underpaid for caring for a large amount of pets. Most shipments of pets were sick and needed veterinary care.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.
