I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.
Come early in the morning to open up the salon and start the computers. I learned a lot about handling different species of dogs. Management was okay.

This job is great for anyone working their way through high school/college and wanting to get a foot in the door for the pet industry (veterinary, training, grooming, etc)-- they will send you to training school or grooming school, if you work for them for x amount of years afterwards.
Fun, easy going environment. Great for college students. This isn't somewhere that offers much room for advancement. Pay isn't great. You get to work alongside animals which is fun.

I had a lot of fun working at PetSmart. My coworkers were great, as well as my managers. The only issues I had were the customers because some were just plain rude, but I did get to meet a lot of dogs.

Depending on which store you work at can depend on your management attentiveness. Some managers are super supportive others aren't. The compensation and pay could be higher but it is retail so I didn't expect it to be 15/hr. I really love the culture at PetSmart. I worked there for 5 years total as a cashier. Now am interviewing for the trainer position. The only reason I got the trainer interview was because a store desperately needed one. Other wise there really is no room for advancement of your store leader doesn't like you.

I loved working at PetSmart on the days everything went smoothly.  It was easy to become overworked given a lack of support staff, but I loved my coworkers and I loved a lot of my customers, and really, what more can you want from a retail job?

Dog trainers here are basically treated as cashiers but with twice the workload and no time to do it on a register. When you’re hired you’re told you will spend some time on the register but the reality is it will be 90% of your job.

Working with dogs is rewarding, informative, and often fun. However, I feel that my Salon Manager was not very interested in guiding me with my first few dogs. She kind of just left me to my own devices, and when I'd ask for advice when uncertain about something, she seemed irritated. Luckily, the more experienced bather was incredibly kind and was more than happy to assist, which ultimately allowed me to learn and perform better on future clients.

Great place to work, you learn so much about the animals. Customers are the best/worst part of the job. It's very gratifying when the customer appreciates the extra work you put in, but it's frustrating when some customers clearly don't care about their animals.

Working in the grooming salon is a lot of fun. My coworkers are nice, genuine people, and management seems to truly care about the employees. You get the sense that corporate always wants to push us to do more and more, though: booking more dogs, answering more calls, making more money. This can become stressful and overwhelm the salon.
Pets were welcome where I worked so that made it a better atmosphere.  The managers were not that good- they often had too much to do with too few people.

There is very little training, especially for a job that requires extensive knowledge about animals and their overall health/well-being. It helps to do your OWN research about the different animals they carry, as the information they give you about them is 1) insufficient 2) not very specific and 3) completly incorrect. If you come into this job expecting to be taught a lot about the little creatures in our care, you’ll be in for an unpleasant surprise. PetSmart doesn’t teach you squat about what our company is supposed to care about most, the animals. Our store was also severely understaffed, so we had to cut corners when it came to cleaning habitats, administering treatment to sick animals, and other basic care duties.
A very happy clean work enviroment. Gives you a sense of purpose and meaning. Nice to see the animals and people together. Itvis a very non toxic work wnviroment.

Certain employees were able to get a set schedule others weren’t certain employees we’re not. The pay is not enough and I wouldn’t consider it a safe environment a lot of things break or we’re understaffed not very clean. They did not do much for social distancing and putting up pixie glass until after two months of re-opening. They sent staff home if it is too slow so they cut your hours, Or if it was too busy you weren’t able to get an actual break

I worked for this company for 8 years and majority of the employees at the store level are hard workers who truly care about staff and animals. Its the field/corporate/upper management who only see dollars and expect you to offer top notch animal care as well as excellent customer service on bare bones budget. Vet care is always encouraged when needed, but it is truly the bare minimum given. Same with employees. There is very little reward for going above and beyond in the workplace. 99% of overtime hours are expected to be worked for free without thanks.

You would think working at petstore would be awesome, but it was the worst place to work. Corporate has no clue what people need or want, management doesn't support its employees. You shouldn't be stressed to go to work worrying how much mental abuse is going to take place. Hardly any hours for part timers and the pay is terrible.
Work-life balance
Pay & benefits

In the time I worked there I came to realize you are just a slave for a lazy manager. Corporate doesn't care about you, or how many times you cover shifts, or the fact that you are there during a pandemic. They won't pay you extra for working in an inviroment where it is very possible you could contract covid. In particular they won't care if you do your job right or wrong, because all management cares about is getting to go home early and not interacting with customers. Good luck getting help or anything for that matter from this company because you will die an early death from stress and no one there will care.

I've worked at two locations for Petsmart. Southlake is awful. In the beginning, it was fantastic. The assistant hotel manager is very immature and childish and will run to the store manager if she has a problem with you in an attempt to get you into trouble. Micromanaging is also a huge issue. The hotel manager was pretty cool. She was very flexible with scheduling. If you ever want to move up into a higher position, forget about it. They have this idea that bringing in outside people will "help" and throw away those of us that have years of experience away like trash. Some people will change the camp rotation consistently throughout the day and put you into the same camp room for hours, usually with "problematic " dogs that they don't want to deal with and if you have children you need to pick up from school, good luck. They'll leave you in said camp room and avoid relieving you with no care of your after work obligations. If you overnight, expect to be left with 80+ dogs by yourself during holidays and you WILL get complaints on why all of the dogs aren't walked. Also, no 15 minute breaks.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

Working for Petsmart has been an eye opening experience for me. The management is poor, as well as the company. Part time employees rarely get acknowledged or receive benefits. Other than that, making relationships with costumers and working with animals is the only plus.

Ever since hours were cut, it made doing the job difficult as we open up to take care of the animals the same time the store opens, which means associates don’t have enough time to do the tasks required. Seeing all sorts of animals coming in the store is interesting, but you also get a fair share of people who have no idea how to care for the animals

The management does not listen they could care less about what is going on good or bad. They only care about if it will effect them or not. Cant help when needed because they don't know how to do the tasks that your asking for help for so i don't see them qualified to be management. They cant see when there is a certain person causing the problem and cant be the strong voice the store needs.

I worked here as a seasonal employee. The management team were all super friendly, and the training was very easy to learn and get the hang of! The overall nature this job gave me was very caring and considerate, and their goals of making pets happy and healthy was very clear the moment I walked in! Everyone also accepted my disability limits and management would let me have a small breather if things got a bit hectic for me to handle. If I could give this company more than five stars, I would!

The work itself can be both difficult or easy it really depends on how well you adapt to the needs of the pet your caring for. Some can be very difficult and others easy, the pets parents can also be difficult or not knowledgeable of the best needs for their dog and it is up to educate them. They don't like that their pet behaves a certain way for grooming but that's just how it is and they can be rude. The most difficult aspect of the job is corporates view on grooming. It is very much a numbers game for them and you are a cog in the machine, a number, and a graph. You may be forced to be over productive to the point of burn-out, anxiety, and frustration/depression. Some dogs may need more time but that doesn't always matter to them. I rarely if ever take a lunch break, how can I when there's to much to do. The best people you'll deal with will probably be your fellow groomers or customers who appreciate what you do.

Never was able to to do the job I was actually hired for and wanted in the first place. Never had a good consistent schedule. Was always volunteered to cover other people's shift, managers don't really know how to teach people and get frustrated when you don't know something. Was left alone to open the store on my second day and had customers get mad at me because i had no idea what to do. Pretty low pay scale.
Decent job. The only part I really didn't like was the pay and working the early morning hours (3am-4am start time). Mangement, when I worked there, was decent.

I have worked for this company for 4 years as a Cashier. They have offered me no possibility for promotion, as well as just generally being nasty towards I and other employees. I make 15¢ above minimum wage with now 4 years of retail experience, and every year I lose my small raise due to minimum wage increasing. The customers that come into our stores are amazing, and I enjoy seeing our regulars and their pets, and they all know me by name, but that's about all that's enjoyable now.
Had flexible scheduling and good management. Work day is basically answering phone calls, scheduling appointments, bathing dog/clipping nails/brushing out.

I enjoy my time at PetSmart, everyday is different and nothing is the same. The pets make your day enjoyable. Your employees are fun and the upper management is your basic upper management so it is what it is. But working at PetSmart has been great.
Have worked at PetSmart for over 2 and a half years, my SL, Mitch, is awesome and has always made work enjoyable. Will be sad to leave as I finished my undergrad.

I absolutely loved working at PetSmart. There were only a few leadership positions so, if you wanted it you really had to show it and work for it. I loved everything about it. Expect to have holidays blocked to request off. The only thing they could improve is pay. I started off as a cashier at my current job making as much as I did there as a supervisor and the job responsibilities there are significantly more important.
Work-life balance

Overall working at Petsmart was probably the best job I’ve ever had. Working as a dog trainer definitely was one of the smartest things I’ve done the pay wasn’t that good but working with the puppies was the best

This company is making things up as it goes. When I first started, I thought the priority here was the well-being of it animals but all the business is looking to do is roll a profit. If you work in the management team, get ready for frequent policy changes, chaotic scheduling, and very little time to accomplish anything.
If you’re willing to deal with the baggage of the store and the team, you can make it far in the company. Management is supportive of you meet that specific person’s needs.

I loved working there.  The work was great and so were the hours. The only thing that could of made it better is if the had more people working there so one group of people didn’t have to work so hard but other then that it was a ok company to work for

I worked here for 3 years and my husband for 5 years. They as a company got rid of all but 4 full time positions that weren’t manager positions. My store specifically had a very rude and sexist store manager, he treated all the girls like they were ditzy and incompetent, and for most he refused to let them do anything but work the register or sort shelves. Luckily I started after my husband with a large knowledge of the pets so I got to work pet care, that was the best part of the job. We took care of the animals and fish and reptiles, we also took care of the shelter cats when the volunteers needed us to. I was lucky enough to have a very smart team around me to teach me so much about animals. The most fun I ever had at work was getting to help families pick out everything they needed for the new pet I helped them learn about!

As a pet hotel employee, I mostly did physical work. Don’t think you’re just gonna be standing in a room with dogs playing all day. You’re going to be seeing a lot of nasty dog fluids and excrement. And you’re going to be cleaning it up! From baths to laundry to the dreaded morning and evening walks, you’re going to be moving a fair amount if your not doing doggy day camp. And doggy day camp isn’t fantastic either. Half the time you’re just standing on achey feet, the other your cleaning doo doo and having to break up fights. Management was fine, I liked my boss, but unfortunately she had to quit when the store refused to move up her position after 5 years at the hotel. Be aware petsmart is still a big, nasty corporation with absolutely no care about you or the animals, not really. And you’re going to see some really gross and questionable stuff.

I worked at Petsmart as a cashier. I started straight out of high school. They were flexible with my schedule for college. Management was fair. The dogs coming in to the store was my favorite part. Easy to become a lead and then move into management.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

As a cashier a typical day was centered on checking customers out quickly. If the shift was slow, I could help stock the shelves in front of the cash register. Sometimes when other sections at the store were busy (ex. petcare) they would send me over to help catch fish or crickets for customers.

Boring on slownights, truely infuriating on busy nights. The "seniors" do little to nothing to help PCS's when preparing the hotel for cleaning, and instead will sit up front and talk to eachother while everyone paid less then them run around with their heads cut off trying to get things done. Higher management never manages the lower management, which has lead them to become lazy, jaded and unsympethetic. If everyone did their job during the day, the Overnight position wouldn't be as exhausting as it is, but as it is now, duties tend to get shirked off to each new shift until it lands on the overnight shift who doesn't get that luxury. Theres also this bizarre feeling of being the "lowest class" as compared to everyone else, as you are often either forgotten or blamed for anything that goes wrong.
Great work environment easy pace everybody easy to get along with other and everybody willing to help you out with what ever task you have to complete
All associates are very nice and respectful.

I worked in the PetCare department for 6 1/2 years during college. This was largely split between typical retail stuff and animal husbandry. Management was uneven in quality, with poor training and bad communication being common. Despite meager wages, they were flexible with the schedule.
Management group is terrible and they aren’t interested in outside hires and see them as a threat therefore do not give them the tools to succeed at their job
I personally had a great experience but I’ve also heard horror stories from other stores. Just be wary of other locations and try to get a good feel for the people there before applying
TLDR: be prepared to work your a** off for little pay or appreciation, while not getting everything done that needs to be done

Great place to start out working, opportunity to grow in the company if you wait long enough. As with all retail jobs, experience wildly varies from place to place and you always have negative experiences with customers.

The hours are short, you definitely get your 40 hours to work. But the management. Unless you’re a manager, it is terrible. No one wants to do their jobs. Store manager doesnt show up often. Leaves many tasks for you to do that the store manager could have easily done.
This job doesn’t offer raises during the pandemic although business is as usual. Starting pay is low so you’re screwed. But you get to work with animals which is nice.

I worked at Petsmart for three years from 2016 to 2019. Overall it was an okay first job to have. It is a good place to work if you love animals. The hours were very inconsistent though. I worked part time and some weeks I would get 15 hours first shift and another week I would get 30 hours last shift.

I worked in the pet care area of the store mostly for about a year and a half. Overall, it was okay. Cleaning the habitats is very time consuming and my managers expected it to be done within an hour which made for some difficult situations. Don't expect to be paid well here. I started out at $9/hr and never got the chance to move up but someone else who I HELPED get hired got started at $9.40..

it was horrible, mean customers that don't care if they are going to put the animal/fish/reptile/bird in danger. they will flip out on you about it. you do have the right to not sell products/animals if you feel they are going to put/be in danger according to their handbook. then management will write you up for it. management never has your back. the animals almost always came in sick. when the avian flu was going around we took birds from a vendor that was sick with it and the birds were sick with and then all the store ended up sick from it. they will do everything in the world to not take the animals to the vet. even when there is a bandfield in their building. they rather "treat them in house" than take them to the vet. a lot of animals die from this. they don't care all care about is making their budget for the week. they don't care if you are sick they still want you to come in especially in the live pet areas. that because they can't keep employees. so the ones  that do stick with it get punished. I took a day off to go to an aunts funeral, they called me 6x during the procession. when i was able to call them and ask what the situation was they threatened to write me up for not being at work when i gave them 3 days notice i was going to a funeral.

All the employees there are nice and I got to know them all very well. The workload is constant, but expectations are placed on improvement not immediate results. Getting into the swing of things is very easy and training is very good.
Fast pace environment! Rating system on the amount of valum is to high. Good at crosstraing. Ok benefits, and good wages for the County I live in. Poor management on safety concerns.
Decent place to work if you love animals. I was only part time and they work with you on hours your availabile.  It's hard to get a full-time position since they only hire managers full-time.

Company could care less about the employees there, they only care about themselves. I won't even get into all the shady stuff. There's a reason they are short staffed and desperately looking for help. This rating is for the warehouse environment not the store.
Find a better place to find a job or hire better managers and they never treat there employees like they should be there attitudes are terrible and they never want to help you

Been there 5 years. During the 5 years I have seen incompetent managers. Store lead doesn't know how to do her job. When I was pregnant, I had a doctors note and nobody listened to it. Was still getting a bunch of big dogs even though I had a 35 pound weight limit. Management let black mold go in the breakroom, salon, and janitor closet forever. Bathroom is always disgusting. Management doesn't care about anybody. Managers don't care about employees being rough with dogs. If you want to be treated like complete garbage. Work here.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.
● Overall

Management does not really care about you outside of work. Schedule is not flexible to your needs and coworkers are often very clique-y. High stress dealing with pleasing both customers and management. Seeing the cats and dogs is a plus though. If you can get past the rude people, being around animals all day is fun.
The only issue I had working there was going in under someone who referred me who happened to have a lot of drama around and I got drug into it. I wanted no part so I respectfully left the company.

Learned a lot of new things working this job such as how to properly care for reptiles, fish, small animals, and birds. My coworkers were polite and courteous and management was generous. An exceptional starting job, as I had little work experience before coming here.
I was promoted quickly because I worked hard and was willing to learn. PetSmart respects animals and how they are cared for, that's important to me. My work meant something.

I've worked for Petsmart for many years in the Bethel DC. The pay is good and work isn't too hard if you aren't lazy. Most of the jobs are timed. Orderfill is easy to make numbers. Anything with the  receiving side is a little tougher. The policies are made up on the fly. What is ok to do one week, may not be ok the next. There is no book or guide to refer to. The managers don't know half the time either what is ok to do policy wise. At the current time, there is no work life balance. We work 60 hours a week because of "scheduled" overtime. It got changed from mandatory during the pandemic so they didn't look like horrible. The people in that building are a mixed bag. You have your good one and your bad ones, like any warehouse. Everytime a change is made, it is usually to benefit the company, not the employee, which in turn had killed morale.
Workplace was open to learning new things and switching around in the store.

Working at PetSmart was quite enjoyable to me. It was a great part-time job for me being that I was a full-time college student. I mainly worked afternoons on the register and occasionally closed in petcare. The managers at my location were amazing and understanding. The usual "rush hour" time was never unbearable or over the top. I regularly worked between 20-29 hours a week with two days off. The only issues I had while working there was how dense some of the customers were, but that's not really PetSmart's fault.
I had a very good time working with my co workers at petsmart while I was there. Stocking the store was always fast paced to be so early in the morning, but me and my team always got the job done.
My favorite job of all time . It was great dealing with the animals and also meeting the pet parents and assisting them with any services that they needed during their visit with us .
the staff in the grooming salon service was terrible. the management of the salon is very hostile, not flexible, and hostile if you make a mistake and yell at you. i had a very terrible experience.

It can be fun working with dogs but you will constantly be yelled at by customers and then told by your manager that it’s “just how the job is”. Customers will treat you like dirt then get free stuff because of the tantrums they throw.

In my 2 years in the company I worked in 2 locations and my experiences was very different in one location I loved working there minus the costumers. In my 2nd location the floor coworkers was amazing!!! But, as for managers I was deeply dissatisfied I was told I don’t know anything for I was just a cashier (while trained as a bather and petcare and in vet school yeah I know nothing) it was all about the sale and the managers don’t want to do much work at all and will call you lazy that you don’t want to do anything and how bad you are at your job while sitting in the office on the phone. The pets I encountered are AMAZING but most costumers don’t want to take your advice so don’t be offended just give your opinion and leave it at that. Pay is 100% not worth working in 3 departments. Be prepared to work the same shift if you work one closing shift you pretty much work them all, same with opening and management won’t let you live down what they have done for you being a raise, full time hours or getting a day off. They are pretty good about giving it but let it be low staffed they won’t hesitate to have you work 7 days that week. Some managers don’t take sides they just talk to you about costumer complaints while others do, but there are favorable employees by store leader 100%.

Typically not very active, as it was a pet store. the busy times were the most enjoyable because there was something to do. the hardest part of the job was just wandering around doing the same things over and over again to look busy.
I worked at PetSmart for a little over 2 years and I loved it. I got to play with fun animals all day and help others with the same love of pets that I had.

Honestly....... What they expect from management is literally IMPOSSIBLE. They require tons of paperwork to be completed, daily inventory logs, the safety walks on the iPad have to take at least 10 minutes long. I spend so much time doing "busy work" that I can't l actually work. A good portion of my day now is spent picking online orders, answer the never ending phone and then running order after order outside to people. After the pandemic, I was enormously disappointed with the way the company responded. It took us about 6 weeks to get gloves, masks, dividers etc and yet we were busier than EVER. They cut payroll so that we were a skeleton crew but with an extremely busy store. My team couldn't even take proper breaks. It became downright unsafe due to the lack of staffing and then shoplifters began running rampant because there was no one to keep an eye on them. I'm happy Petsmart stepped up and gave all associates a sizeable bonus because my team absolutely deserves it, but I was shocked that managers got nothing at all. I close 4 nights a week and there is no work life balance. If you enjoy cleaning up dog mess all day and lifting very heavy dog food and cat litter this is the job for you.

Worked in hotel. Horrible health standards for both pets and employees. Our first aid kit was over ten years expired. Manager and assistant manager were non existent. Front desk would not provide back up when needed. Staff was undertrained. They would not clean walls of kennels or the gutters when cleaning the rooms. Playrooms would be filled beyond capacity with red tagged dogs or/and dogs with past documented aggression. Which lead to dogs getting hurt and two deaths, over three years. Front desk and management did not care. They are more concerned about making money then the health and safety of employees and pets.
Very stressful working in the salon. Too many groomers and too many dogs at one time. Impossible to get anything done. Did not work with the schedule I needed at all
Hard worker... Took care of all the pets and made relationships with the pet parents. Hours were good pay was decent but all in all it was an amazing experience.
Loads of associate support and resources. Team members are encouraged to cross train departments. A team member always has the potential to develop management skills and advancement.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

this is a bad place to work. They are not good about training new people. You get about 2 days and then get thrown in the deep end. You have to be ON TOP of your breaks, or you will not get them. The management has no idea what they're doing. We get no compensation for working during covid-19, and a lot of us got laid back with little warning, and then they cut contact. We're not treated very well.

Job was fun and kept me busy all day. I learned that it's best to work smart and efficiently than trying to get things done quickly. Managers and employees were kind and helpful. Enjoyed working for this company very much. Hardest part of the job was dealing with difficult customers. Most enjoyable part of the job was helping customers and seeing their pets that they brought along with them.

I got the job as part time to save up for a car. It’s a good way to make some $ and it’s an easy job, especially if you are knowledgeable about pets. BUT management at my PetSmart specifically was absolutely awful. There’s 6 different managers and each one has their own way of doing things which is completely unorganized. They’d all tell me something different and you could never get a straight answer about anything! They’d also tell me to skip my 15 minute breaks all the time cause “they didn’t have anyone to take my place”. I literally got one 15 minute break when I was new and anytime after that they said I couldn’t go.

This was one of my favorite jobs. Unfortunately it is for kids and young adults to work. They way underpay and way overwork for the amount of pay. I met people that I had and have strong relationships with. I had never hung out with a manager before. I’ve never had a manager that was nice though until here. I love the customers(usually) and I love the animals I got to see ever day.

Be ready to give your life away to a company that just takes control of your life, This company will work you like a slave. You sign up for a shift and they make you work more than what your shift. For example I work 3rd shift. And out of the blue they have me work two extra days. So I'm working 3 12 HR shifts plus two days after that, Just because it's Mandatory, Also these people don't care about your well being weather it be Mental or Physical, They Just care about the almighty Dollar. I can go on all day about how bad they are. But if want to work here prepare to be miserable.

I absolutely hate my job. I’m a cashier and it’s the worst position in the store. It truly is. The turn over rate for that position is ridiculous. I’ve made it known to management I want to switch to pet care and I’ve been ignored so that’s cool. Also for COVID no one got hazard pay or a bonus. My yearly review came up and I got a whopping $0.15 as my raise. Yep, im done. Finding a new job as of right now.

They are an amazing company to work for with great benefits and great work ethic, a lot of space and options for moving up within the company and gave lots of hands on training the employees were all wonderful and nice aswell
Good company values that help make it a rewarding job. Most employees genuinely care about pets and helping pet parents give them the best life possible.

hours are cut everyday. You are lucky if you get 20 hours a week. No full time employees allowed to be hired. Good beginner Job. Not good for families. Pay sucks. You only get a percentage raise every year and thats maybe 10 cent

management will tell you whatever you want to hear regarding schedules and job opportunities but there is no follow through or trust.  Management is extremely disorganized so everything from onboarding to training takes forever.  No respect paid to availability.
This is a good place to work. Staff is very friendly and fair. I do wish that the pay was a bit higher but its not a big deal. Would recommend working here

Very hard work and hard on the body. The labor required is not conductive to the time they give you to complete an order. You mainly have to over exert yourself to make production rate each week. And even then you still may not get it. And your highly pressured to do so. Pay is great but not to the equal amount of hussel you have to do to make production rate. Actually not even the pay is worth the slaving you endure. Company has a high turnover rate for years now.

To many rotten eggs ruining for those of us who work hard. The communication is poor when trying to do the right thing. I was a victim of retaliation for speaking up and no one helped me even though its a serious violation.

Good management is a bit of a gamble, depending on location; But I guess that's any job. My coworkers are great, that's the primary reason I've stayed. The COVID situation really exposed company values and how much (or how little, rather) corporate values its employees. Our location is BUSY and shifts are usually constant run & go and often understaffed/underscheduled. So before you apply, I'd consider looking up some rough foot traffic stats on the location you're considering. Register is easy. Stocking is simple, but requires some degree of urgency and organization. Pet care is a LOT of customer service & educating pet parents. A lot of rushing around and trying to keep up with everything. BUT, if you're looking for some new knowledge, you will learn a ton.

Loved working with customers dogs, absolutely a dream. Under paid for very strenuous/dangerous work. The salon leader at my location would beat dogs, choke dogs, and become overall aggressive towards pets that weren’t 100% compliant. Multiple times she would trim dogs nails so short they would bleed for upward of 30 minutes and she would never seek vet attention. And the store leader and salon leader were friends so she ignores anything you bring up to her. Got bullied by the salon leader until I ended up quitting, crying to the store manager was pointless. Then all the other long term employees in the salon quit too due to the horrendous management.

Grooming the dogs is fun, but big decisions for the salon are made by the district people who have zero experience grooming. Pay is based on commission, potential to make a lot of money or none at all. Pressure from higher ups to groom more dogs, sometimes more than your physically able to. Can be highly stressful, but the super cute dogs that come in make it worth it. Helps open your eyes to the different types of neglect people can have towards their animals, mostly cast matted dogs that come to get shaved down once a year. Satisfaction for dematting those dogs, knowing for a short period they will be comfortable. Having worked for two different stores, the management is always randomized. First manager was always against us and it was always us vs the manager & the pet parents. Current manager defends us and learns both sides of the story.

You can have a great team, but that doesn't stop the overwhelming amount of things happening all at the same time from corporate ideas coming into store unplanned. They don't look at demographics so a store with a lower income area needs more staff but they will not give labor and don't understand why they cant achieve the same as areas in higher demographic areas. The amount of people you have working or labor available to work affects safety within the team and therefore some stores must be unsafe to succeed. The only person who is salary is the store leader so unless that one person is willing to work with no balance the store doesn't achieve success as measured by the company. Which is not based on sales so even if your doing well from a sales standpoint other factors are seen as a failure but if your sales slip your also seen as a failure so there isn't a great game plan. I understand its a giant company but lets make it more comprehensive and easy to train associate seeing as no one really gets trained to do there job.
Some managers were supportive where as others made working there more challenging. This was also true for other staff, but management had a more significant effect per shift.

Working with the animals was the best perk, really no benefits besides discounts on pet items and food. Management was ok, could have been better at backing up pet care associates when they didn’t want unfit pet parents to own fish like betta. There were so many times my manager would just shut me down and let pet parents walk out with the bare minimum for their fish.
They treat their employees like they are worthless. They dont care about the wellbeing of their employees. The only good thing about this company is the benefits

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

Doesn't work well with military personnel. Acted as if they were never told that I was being deployed. Tried to tell me that I would lose my job because I hadn't been on the schedule in almost a year due to the military and I had two weeks (IN THE MIDDLE OF MY DEPLOYMENT) to get put back on the schedule and show up to work even though I am currently 7,000 miles away.

This company's management does not care about you at all if you're not making them a lot of money. Extremely poor and unreasonable management. Lord forbid you have health problems because they do not care or respect that at all. Don't make appointments any sooner then a month and a half and just PRAY that you have it off because they don't care and will schedule you. Don't stand up for yourself or others against management or you'll get a write up. If you want to feel like a human being then apply somewhere else.

This was my first job and it taught me a lot about the proper way to take care of animals. I cleaned, fed, and medicated the small animals  and fish daily. The most stressful part of the job was seeing how uneducated some customer can be about the care of animals since the costumer often doesn’t realize that animals need more than just a small cage/ tank and one type of food. Other than the stressful customers it felt rewarding to take care of all the animals and fish. I ended up learning a lot, however it does take being interested to learn about it. It’s good for a first job since pay and hours aren’t great.
● Work-life balance

While the compensation for this position is a perk, as in addition to hourly pay you can be eligible for bonuses, the culture has turned into something so different than what is advertised. Employees are pushed to their limits by corporate and store management to the point of burnout. This is unfortunate because there are some wonderful employees that deserve to enjoy working for the company.
Petsmart was my first job and management helped me learn work skills I would need without being rude or looking down on me. It was a really friendly environment and welcoming.
One of the greatest thing working here is that you see different animals on a daily and the not so good days were the smells occasionally but other than that it was perfect

My coworkers were the best part of working for this company. It's not an awful place to work, however, I don't understand where they find managers from. I was consistently lied to about my pay, and job security during COVID. A girl that had been working there for 3 months was receiving higher pay than me for the same job when I had been there for 3 years. I was in-valued as an employee and the lack of integrity is unacceptable in management. I had an awful experience in the last month I stayed with this company. Take everything they say with a grain of salt. They will tell you what you want to hear just to get you off their back and then never deliver.

They are sexiest, only small females work they. They put you in uncomfy situations and make you work 13 hour shift. Customers are allowed to walk all over you. They do not care about ethical values, overall it's like 4/10. Nothing  is ever enough for them.
Management is very supportive and helpful when you are a hard worker. Will help you advance in the company. Pay can be better for the job requirements.
I can't speak for all petsmarts but i adore the one i work at. The managers are nice and try their best to work with me so i am not burnt out every shift.

I had been with Petsmart for nearly two years as a bather/stylist apprentice. Before I was even hired, I expressed my interest and desire to go to their grooming academy, in order to become a groomer/pet stylist. Managment at both stores I have worked at has been unsupportive, and unprofessional. If you want to become a groomer, you are better off going elsewhere and training on the job, as opposed to waiting for petsmart to send you to their academy.

Working here I can honestly say they do not pay you nearly enough for the work you do. This is not a good job if you’re not comfortable being in the store completely by yourself. You get payed $10 an hour to do a million things in one night and also handle health charts and monitoring sick animals. You are responsible with 40 animals on the weekend and more if it’s closer to the holidays. The managers are extremely unprofessional and they aren’t understanding at all. They tell you if you’re not comfortable walking animals then don’t, your safety comes first however when you tell them you weren’t comfortable they are mad at you? They are so busy telling you the things you didn’t do right in the morning and never tell you the things you do very good at. It’s extremely discouraging. This is really funny considering they don’t do much and they sit around till the store opens. The closers leave you with messes at night when you come in even though they are supposed to have majority of things done so you can focus on your duties however they never seem to do them. They leave me with tons of laundry and dishes as well as five or more dogs sitting in their room with accidents. This place is also infested with giant cockroaches that are around the dogs. Working here i’ve learned two things: 1) I will never take my dog here 2) I am worth so much more than this job. Guys, I’ve worked plenty of jobs and this job payed me the least out of all of them and I did the most work here. This job is worth $15+ so if you do decide to work here I suggest working in a different department because they

The majority of my customers were fantastic, there were just the few who wouldn’t listen to my vast knowledge of animals and didn’t believe me when I told them about the work, effort, and MONEY that goes in to any and every pet. Not to mention the condition some of our animals came in (don’t look up Petsmart animal suppliers, it’s awful). The managers were horrid. I was the lowest manager and I had to do everyone else’s job and anytime I tried to help the unappreciated employees with something I got fussed at. The distract manager only cares about promoting men and if you even question why things are done a certain way way you’re written off as not following policy. They allow sexist and racist managers to work there knowingly and after multiple employees and customers have pointed it out. You’re required to have open availability (basically on all 24/7) and if you try and change it for a second job, school, or even religious stuff you are fussed at, overruled, or challenged on the validity of your reasons. And good luck getting full time, they’ll work you like you’re full time and expect you to be available like you’re full time but as soon as you start getting to that average hours you’re suddenly down to working once or twice a week. Also they pay terribly. I’d run far away!! I would give negative stars if possible.
Liked my time here! Good job during high school. Managers were fair and understanding. I enjoyed working with a variety of people and also helping customers when they had questions.

While I worked at the hotel, I started out really excited! Who doesn't want to work with dogs all day?? The truth was it was very stressful-- constantly understaffed and overworked. We had a terrible turnover rate, the manager would hire a few new people and most of them would only last a month before quitting because of the stress.

Great part time job.  The managers are helpful and the animals are fun.  It can get stressful as corporate will try to cut costs by cutting hours which then upsets customers when lines get long.  Normal retail issues.
It was a stressful job at best that didn't pay for the work they wanted done. The employees I worked with were all great people and I enjoyed coming in every day to work expecting something new.

The culture in my store was great, everyone got along well for the most part. However we could not keep a store leader (SL) or assistant store leader (ASL) for longer than a few months, most likely because of difficult upper management who aimed to instill fear in leaders rather than inspiring them, asking for input, or offering assistance/guidance. This does not seem to be the case for all districts, but this one specifically.
Management does not equally distribute hours. The same employees stay with 8 hours a week, while others enjoy 30, and this has nothing to do with availability.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

This was a great place to work as a part-time job. Definitely high-paced and busy through the holidays. Definitely needs to have an empathetic person who is willing to listen to pet parents talk about their animals.

Best job I’ve ever had. It was laid back (most of the time) and I loved everyone I worked with. You saw the cutest animals—from puppies to leopard geckos. You would get some strange customers with strange request, people would expect you to solve their problems with their pet when they should go to a VET. Price matching was a nightmare. But overall a great experience.

I didn't start/stay for pay...I truly LOVE animals so the job was great to me in that aspect. My personal opinion is that they should offer more compensation/hours to associates. Employees deal with alot when it comes to PetParents and even WITH proof otherwise...corporate tends to believe every word a customer says in complaint. If thin skin...not the job for you

The management staff is unprofessional. You can do a good job however if they have created in their mind that they do not like you. Figure it out what goes on. I am not being bitter.  I just do not think the dogs are properly cared for.
It's a good job, some of the the groomers are nice and the animals are great to work with once you're trained.

Managers change frequently, employees bigger between one another and cause unnecessary drama between one another. Training was bad for grooming, had to get 3 did teachers with 3 different styles of work to teach a group of students in 2 weeks. Very difficult to get basics if trainers and managers keep quitting. To get a good check you would have to fight each other to get bookings.
I liked working there my co workers were very nice and would help if I needed it. It would get very busy around the afternoon but thats the best part.

This company was one of the worst companies I have every worked for. They really suck with scheduling, letting you know if they have changed the schedule. They also do not do competitive pay. And pay there employees nothing. I hated working with this company.

There’s not enough time to list everything wrong with this location when I worked there.  Overall it’s a fun job but management absolutely ruins it.  There may be different management now but when I was there it was awful.  And when I filed a complaint with corporate they “listened” to my complaint but then did nothing about it and the management I complained about retaliated.  I worked in the hotel, out in the store, and as one of the trainers.  I would have continued working there if it wasn’t for the management.  Also they do the thing that should be completely illegal of giving me JUST under 40 hours so I wouldn’t qualify for benefits.  And then they would yell at me if I crossed into overtime pay after THEY called me in.  Also the pay was awful.  I’m pretty sure it was minimum wage and each quarter you could get a .25 raise.  You read that right, TWENTY FIVE CENT RAISE.  They also started out not giving me my legally required 15 minute breaks, meanwhile one of the managers would take smoke breaks about 10 times per shift.  I really do miss all the dogs I saw on a regular basis though.  And some of the pet parents were great and I miss them as well.

Pet Care Associate at Petsmart was my first job and for a first job, it was great. My only complaint is that the animals are often seen as inventory. I had one manager throw dead bearded dragons at me. Not all managers will be that harsh.

If you work the hotel be ready for 8 hours straight in a room with 10-12 dogs by yourself with no bathroom breaks or safety except for a small citronella can. Employees have to go into every room regardless if they get bit and sent to the hospital. You also are paid base pay for making sure yourself and people's dogs don't die or kill each other.
You can always learn something here. Have open hours for working and you can almost get full time work. There great people to work for and I've learned a lot from them.
Love the people and pets! Learning something new everyday was normal. The chance to move up was easy. Overall great company with great benefits! All for the love of pets
It was fun but cashier was not for me.  Managers were kind and considerate. Always continuing education on products and interaction with venders.   Stable job to work at

I was very happy there until covid19 laid us off! If you love dogs like I do, then you will be satisfied. Everything was fun when it came to play rooms. Only problem was breaking up a dog fight! It's quite the adrenalin!

The animals were poorly housed when I got there. There was dust and cat hair so thick that it'd choke you. Some of the cats had fleas or other issues that hadnt been taken care of. The cats would also fight often because they were overcrowded

I enjoyed my 6 years at the Petshotel at Petsmart . I learned many things and enjoyed being with  the dogs . I treated each dog like it was my own . In turn I felt like the dogs and their family were like my own family .
I like shopping here. Not enough employees to help high prices.  I never can find someone to get crickets for me. When they call for someone noone shows up. Always understaffed

I was a leader at my store within a month of being hired. What I wasn't prepared for was the constant drama within management. My store leader and assistant store leader constantly degraded other employees and talked negatively about them. It wasn't a professional environment. I never received any support from my store leader. During my six years I witnessed many great employees being run off by poor upper management.
I liked grooming dogs, everyone loves dogs, and it's cool to transform them and make them feel good! I really did love it. But my manager made the work environment hostile for me, so I had to leave.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

They offer room to move up in position just to get you in there and promise to promote you. Then they give promised jobs to family or friends. There is too much politics going on instead of crunching down and getting work done.

Offers a great work wife balance with benefits and many incentives outside the salary . The company offers  opportunities for advancement and creates an inclusive environment for associates. Of course being around dogs all day is a plus.
Fun place to work at but manager has favorites and makes u feel your not doing a good job. The job is pretty easy with decent pay tho, this job Is mostly for students.

Really loved the campus and on-site benefits (cafeteria, animals at work, many events) and the culture is one of the best in the Phx area.  However, some managers were not very seasoned and spent most of day chasing issues which did not need detailed oversight or micro-managing by saying you can do something the way you want.  Then, they turn around and take your work away and night and change everything just for you to find out in the morning.  This happened multiple times.  Not all teams are like this, but my mgmt chain was definitely an all or nothing, 'good 'ol boy' team.  Nothing about capability & results, more about if they like you or not.  I saw this many times also. Just be careful and suck up to the boss hard if you feel you are on the outside.  Some managers over-react to minor situations and lose site of the primary goals.  some managers continue to grow your responsibility to a point were you are doing other peoples jobs and your manager plays it off as "because I said so".  Inexperienced/immature middle mgmt approach.

If you want to work for a company who doesn’t care about its employees this is the place for you!! I have worked here multiple years and I can tell you this place is going down the drain. I’ve been through 5 different managers since first starting here. Nobody wants to work for this place because the management is so very poor. Every single manager I’ve encountered only really cares for a paycheck and not their employees. Makes sense since that’s where all the money goes, cut hours and spend that money on already overpaid managers  Do yourself a favor and work for a place that actually cares about its employees

PetSmart is a wonderful establishment. You learn a lot about all kinds of different animals. If you are a lover to all animals then PetSmart is the place for you. The only down fall is the pay, hours, and depending on the store, the management. It is a part time job and you would only be payed under $10. The managers are the ones that have a full time position making way more than the associates that do most of work anyways.They hire so many people that your hours get cut. You’d probably only work 2-3 days out the week. PetSmart is more of a side job. Not one to make a living out of. All the work that the associates put in aren’t paid enough for the work they do. All the cleaning, rude customers, and knowledge thats needed isn’t being paid enough to do.

Petsmart isn’t the greatest place to work. It depends on your management but mostly everyone looks out for themselves and ceos couldn’t care less on how crazy a store is they won’t give you hours to staff the store.

I, personally, loved working at petsmart and would definitely go back. I met so many dogs every day and I got to care for the animals on the floor. The customers were some of the best I've experienced in retail which is always a plus. The only thing that was particularly hard was when I had to keep myself from taking all the animals home with me.

I was given way too little hours, didn't feel respected, my requests to be put back on pet care were constantly ignored. I was working once or twice a month, they would not give me more hours even though I asked.
Working with pets is therapeutic for me. Customers can be rude at times but never stoped me from doing my job. Its a good job if you like animals. I enjoy it.

This company has laid people off due to Covid-19 who have been employed for 20+ years with the company. They don’t care about worker rights. They don’t give raises. You do 5 different jobs for the pay of slightly above minimum wage.
the typical day pre covid19 was pretty simple joyful and simple with some easy to difficult tasks now that covid is a thing it had gotten very stressful

Pet Care department is overworked and underpaid. They are given very little time to do a long list of important tasks. They are required to know a lot of information and to care for many different animals. Pay is low for the amount of work you have to do.

There’s times when I feel defeated when pet parents clearly do not care for their animals but it’s definitely rewarding when someone listens to your advice. People at register can be stressful and complain about things that at my level I have zero control over.

This was a great job. I would go back to this job. Great pay great benefits and the supervisors and hr departments wants everyone to succeed. They also have great vacation periods and will allow as much ot as you need .
I would load and unload shipment I would get shipment ready to be shipped to costumer and other locations would also restock shelves would learn other skills to

Probably my favorite job that I held, I worked there for over 2 years after all. I loved worked around animals, and my coworkers were a lot of fun. The place was also really good at working with your schedule. Unless it was holiday season, you almost always got times you asked for off, and even then they tried their best to work with you. The only big downside with working there was that higher ups kept constantly cutting down on hours, and there was the occasional manager who had a hot temper that would cause people to end up quitting. By the time I left, the majority of people that I had started with had left, and now that I'm gone, there's like 2 people left there that were there when I was, and they're in the grooming salon, which rarely changes staff.
Go I at 4am to Work the truck and get out at 8am the job is an ok gig..only problem is people take advantage of people kind heart and they really show no care in people’s feelings but there self

The people are mostly great .It can be very demanding .Working well with people is a must no fear of reptiles and rodents and some knowledge is helpful .willingness to work many hours is often needed .Easy going management

I was literally thrown in after only a few days of being there, and this was back in February when things were calmer and less busy. So they had the time to train me, they were just lazy. Then when stuff hits the fan and people go crazy with shopping, I don’t know how to do certain things or I’m making mistakes, then they have the audacity to get mad at me

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.
Hot and humid for the workers and the pets. Black mold on the ceiling tiles where the pets board. Not enough workers to clean up the fecies in the kennels in a apprioate manner etc...

The animals are not properly kept. The advice given for animals is not good enough. Upper management only cares about sales. You can and will be fired over dumb circumstance. Customers at some locations are toxic and a lot of the customer service for animals is that the customer is always right, but with petcare that is far from the truth.
A typical day at work would be making sure the animals were ok. Help anyone to walk through the doors. And to be gentle when it came to the animals. .

While in college I worked at the petshotel. It was very long hours and lots of cleaning. A lot of people just get hired and they don't care to do their share of work which will eventually catch up to other shifts. The overnight never cleaned kennels making a good hour of cleaning when you first start. Work every holiday. My direct boss in the hotel was amazing. Store managers revolved, the last one I had was a nightmare. She relied on others to do her scheduling, payroll, supply ordering. Her ops manager was cool though.
If you wanna work hard they don’t want you there.

I started when they first opened in the Midwest. I worked there for twelve years as their dog trainer; #1 in top-grossing training sales every month of every year fo the twelve. The only reason I stayed that long is it was a commission job. With the above numbers, I assure you that I not only made a lot of money BUT, I made enough that corporate left me alone. I was the reason the 'current' store director, district & regional managers got their yearly bonuses, so they left me alone as well. Most trainers left after two to three MONTHS! Why? Because they couldn't produce the 'numbers'. Why? Because management wouldn't leave them alone. Why? Because corporate wouldn't leave management alone.
Loved working here! As with any retail job the hours aren’t always favorable but it’s a fun place to work! The team was great and always worked together to get the job done.
Good management, nice people, able to work around a busy schedule, fair pay, overall a fun place to work, especially getting to see all the puppies!!!

It’s good if you’re a college student, all the managers try to be nice and understanding, but you must come to them with your needs. Job can be fun depending on what you do. Customers can be cool most of the time unless they don’t understand the needs for their pets.

During covid it has been pretty rough. Working with a skeleton crew, and starting to get very busy is a bit stressful. However, the company in general is great. They truly do care about the animals and that is refreshing. Fun place to work as long as you don't mind bugs or handling small animals or birds or fish.
It has all the pit falls of retail . Everyone is over worked and unhappy. Customer base  seems to be particularly petty in this industry as well but you do the best with what you have.

Managers are essentially do it all employees that have to clean up animal feces, push carts, and operate registers—all while running a store with minimal resources and heavy pressure to meet unrealistic KPMs from upper management. Company often does not have managers/employees back when employees have encounters with unreasonable and disrespectful customers—whom frequently demonstrate abusive and belittling  behavior. Customers tend to treat employees terribly and let their animals  defecate all over, and then expect you to pick it up (which you will have to). Overall, employees are treated poorly and hours are all over the places. Managers have to schedule employees for a couple hours here and there and crazy times (2AM-6AM, 4AM-12PM, you name it, it’s all in the table). Everyone at store level is abused and taken advantage of, while the cooperate SSG (Store Support Group) thinks of silly ideas for stores to try to implement. In store teams are barely marking ends meet with minimal resources and little or no appreciation. Company always wants things done better and more sales(way more), but they don’t want to pay for more employees or hours. Cooperate employees, DMs, RVPs, and SSG folks love do surprises visits to criticize and intimidate, and they have an attitude of arrogance and superiority. If there’s an up coming executive visit, or if there’s possibly the store receives an audit; you will work more hours, under higher stress than you could probably imagine. It’s a demeaning place to work. If you can avoid it (which I couldn’t), you should. Keep looking, this place will
Love learning about pets and pet food. Fun job to get started in the pet industry. Get to see dogs every day and interact with people who share your interest in pets.
Generally thought it was a pretty good company for today's job market. Found out the hard way that they do NOT treat employees right. Corporate SUX!!!!
It is actually pretty good. I really enjoy working with the animals. I enjoy the hours as well! It’s pretty decent job if your looking for a second job or just for some extra money
The salon is a stressful environment but the floor is a great place to work. In the salon dogs always get taken off of you, so you don’t get dogs then get in trouble for not doing any.

Best for entry level or part time job seekers who hold multiple jobs or are also going to school.  Super flexible with your schedule, friendly coworkers, great team, supportive managers. Animals are the highlight of the job (as an animal lover).

I'm an Assistant Manager at Petsmart and my Co workers have been amazing. I am paid very fairly as well, my issue is with my boss the Store manager. She often prevents people from taking breaks, and uses fear tactics to make people listen. As a person she's wonderful, but to be leading a Petsmart she is failing and workers have mentioned it to me as well.
Care for associates has went down the drain over the years and I’ve worked at several locations that have poor management that do not lead by example or encourage associates.

It's entirely up to managers how much you like your job. I loved my basic tasks of cleaning habitats and assisting customers, even with the occasional difficult one, but management changes made it unbearable. The company as a whole started prioritizing in-store animals as a whole and the management really makes a difference on how well theyre vared fir store tonstire.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

I worked for PetSmart in the PetsHotel for about 6 months. While I was there my duties included taking care of the cats and dogs boarding, supervising playtimes, feeding the animals, and general cleaning duties. The animals were really the best and only good part in working there. The downside at my store was the management team. They very rarely communicated with one another so if you told one manager something then the chances were that the rest of the management team wasn’t going to hear about it. For example: I was injured on the job and I informed the manager on duty what had happened. When I called later to say I was going to have to seek medical treatment the manager I spoke with had not heard I had been hurt and then proceeded to try and bargain with me about coming in since they didn’t have their act in line with the staffing. I went out on comp for a couple weeks while my injury healed and when I came back I gave the note to another manager who lost it even though I watched her take a copy. I was later injured again when the manager on duty that night failed to tell me there was an issue with some of the equipment. Between the repeated injuries, the lack of staffing, the poor equipment upkeep, and so many other issues, I ended up leaving. It’s good as a side gig if you need the money and you love animals but the management was awful at my store.
Though they have a propensity for promoting bad managers, the environment can still be positive. There are a lot of good employees. Management suffered when the company was bought out by bank firm.

It’s a good starting out job. You learn about the pets that are sold and how to properly care for them. The best part is seeing a little one come and get their first fish or hamster. If you don’t mind varying hours and little pay it’s not the worst place to be. Management is all over the place. Too much talk, too little action
The animals themselves create a very positive calm and exiting work experience everyone seems to equally care about the stores maintenance and finding all pets a home.

Like with any company there's the business side of petsmart And it must be balanced with With the interactive part. that being said the interactive part with pets and their families was the most enjoyable I had any job.

I was very excited to start working at petsmart because I love animals and was excited to be working with other people who love them too. Boy, do I wish I never worked there. The “training” I received was about 2 hours of staring at a screen and taking quizzes and then 2 shifts of shadowing other workers (who hardly explained what they were doing). Then I had to open the pet care department completely on my own at 6 in the morning. Working with the animals was fun and cute at first until the first shipment of animals who came in tiny boxes terrified and sick. So many animals died, some in my arms. To make matters worse and more depressing, I had a manager yell at me, telling me it was MY fault that the animals were dying (I was probably the only person there who tried to take good care of them). The management was incredibly rude and condescending, even made me cry once (and frequently made another manager cry). When I needed to cut back my hours due to schooling, they consistently over scheduled me and told me they’d cut back my hours If I did my work better. The majority of my coworkers were also kind of “cultish” and very judgmental towards me and I felt like a total outcast. To put the icing on the cake, I got ringworm from one of the sick guinea pigs ON MY FACE! I also got very very sick and was berated by one of my managers for not being able to come in and I ended up just quitting. Do yourself a favor, don’t work here.
TLDR: I was a cashier for 2yrs, got laid off cuz of Covid-19, could not collect unemployment cuz I didn't make enough hours.Thanks for nothing PetSmart.

It is a good retail job however it is not perfect. Lots of tasks to complete in small amounts of time. Time management is key. This is a team effort, to keep the store and the animals within acceptable standards.

I worked at Petsmart for about a year and it had its regular ups and downs, such as bad customers and good animals to work with. Personally I thought they focused way too strongly on the customer aspect, not taking into account that we sell living breathing animals that need attention more than that full grown adult that could easily google her question. Covid19 hit and this company showed its true colors. They didnt change their hours until state mandated, no paid time off, no hazard pay, they didn't even limit customers in store or enforce the people to stay away from us. No one was required to wear a mask and we were only cleaning once a day if even then. Also, this awful company cut half of its staff down using Covid19 as an excuse, and ran us ragged. We were making more profit than ever, were as busy as black Friday, but every single day. And they decided it would be a good idea to cut staff to save money. That money going directly to the CEOs pockets since none of us were given hazard pay, and anyone who was given a raise recently had it revoked. I could go on and on, but long story short, on a small scale your store would be fine, but the company as a whole doesn't give a **** about you.
Fun environment (who doesn't love seeing puppies at work every day) good people, who are supportive.  Always something new to learn and ways to improve.

Management sucks, poor pay, and they play favorites. Worked 5 years and they kept giving the hours to the new people. You’re expected to do more sales than full time employees in the span of five hours.

If things don’t get finished on a day shift and grave didn’t have time it’s there fault.  They were constantly under minded.  The manager gossiped like  no other. It felt uncomfortable. I felt stuck on graveyard. I didn’t wanna be on graveyard. Who does. I’m a hard worker but felt undervalued. Eh typical graveyard. Even tho who else is gonna work that horrid shift?

It's an okay place to work. The pay isn't bad, but the raises are nearly non-existent. The longer you work for the company, the more they begin to take you for granted. Local management is pretty standard, but corporate, is corporate.

As a corporation goes, Petsmart is better than most. Our store management tries to make us feel like a team and a family. Retail operations are retail, rarely much nice in retail! We get discounts on purchases and a 50% discount on house brands. That's great. Holidays management buys us great food !
I loved working here as a pet care lead years ago. I felt valued for my hard work and care for the animals and customers.  I was very happy here. I didn't have any bad experiences here.

Horrible company that cares about nothing more than getting more money in their pocket. Will throw their employees under the bus to get that. Dosen't care about the well being of the animals they sell, will sell to people with no cages, for carnivals, horrible set ups, you name it. Treats their groomers like garbage. Dosen't care when they seriously injure a dog and let's the groomer keep grooming dispite multiple of the same injury type and drives the good groomers into the dirt by pushing them to take more and more dogs in a day until they litteraly breakdown and get hurt due to stress.

It was so fun working with and taking care of so many different animals every day i worked! Customers are usually nice and even fellow employees are very welcoming as well! If you want to work with animals but need a flexible schedule, PetSmart is the place for you!

When i first started i had fun but they truly dont pay enough for what you have to do and they do not stand up for employees. also the biggest thing is how they handled covid-19 pandemic ..... terrible

Maybe we're just lucky, but our management team is excellent. I have worked in the Hotel for about a year now. Our clients can be a pain sometimes but I am there for the animals. The company supports and donates time and money to animal adoption and charities. I love working here. My favorite job I have EVER had in 28 years of working.

If you love all types of animals you'll love working here. Other than that, it's a relaxing low key place to work as a retail associate. Managers and Team Leaders are put under very stressful work conditions with demanding management.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

Horrible management, even district leaders don’t have your back. The regule associates are expected to do a lot but management does not help at all. As a store leader I tried to help and implement respect. But no luck.

If you enjoy working with animals and people it's a fun place to work! Co-workers are super friendly! Customers can sometimes be a bit difficult however petsmart has a good balanced policy of taking care of customer happiness as well as employee happiness (for example I worked in the grooming salon and if a customer wasn't happy we would offer a discount next time fix anything we were able to etc. But of the customer was overly rude such as cussing and yelling and treating us badly we could deny them service in our salon). The pay is not competitive with other shops, but it's a good place to start a grooming career. Being a team player is valued and will get you a long way with your co-workers. Especially in the salon we all always need help at some point. It's hard when you're new and just learning and you need more help then you can give, but helping where you can will make others with more experience more willing to prioritize helping you when needed. Over all I loved working at PetSmart.

I spent my time here while I was earning my associates degree. Flexible hours and great team to work with HOWEVER I will say that atmosphere changes from store to store as I have helped at several locations.

I like to just come in to work and do my job right and correctly and be safe and always be aware of your surroundings I want to do the best job I can with no drama and when my work is finished then just go home I’m actually working in a mailing place right since January 2020 as a machine operator

I loved this job, it was the perfect job to have during college. In the beginning (2018) there were the best managers, but since I left the management has spiraled downhill. My old coworkers have mostly all quit because the managers that corporate sent were so ruthless and belittling.
